{{Orphan|date=November 2013}}
'''Chako Paul City''' (or '''Shakebao''') is a fictional town of 25,000 all-female residents located in northern [[Sweden]], reports of which surfaced in [[China|Chinese]] press agencies [[Xinhua]] and [[Harbin News]] in 2009.<ref>[http://www.thelocal.se/22476/20091005/ Landes, David. "Chinese media tempted by fantasy of women-only Swedish town" ''The Local'' 5 Oct 09] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009111035/http://www.thelocal.se/22476/20091005/ |date=October 9, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="shanghaiist">{{cite web | url = http://shanghaiist.com/2009/10/09/the_complete_story_of_the_fabled_sw.php | title = The complete story of the fabled Swedish Lesbian City | last = Chow | first = Elaine | publisher = [[Shanghaiist]] | date = 2009-10-09 | accessdate = 2009-10-28 }}</ref><ref name="Australian"/> Said to have been founded in 1820 by a wealthy, man-hating widow, men are banned from entering the town and most of its desperate, sex-starved inhabitants have turned to [[lesbianism]]. Immediately following the reports, millions of Chinese men swamped Swedish tourist companies with requests for information about it.<ref name="Australian">{{cite web | title = Sex-mad men search for 'lesbian' Chako Paul City | url = http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,26182241-12377,00.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091009123148/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C25197%2C26182241-12377%2C00.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2009-10-09 | publisher = The Australian | date = 2009-10-08 | accessdate = 2009-10-28 | quote = The myth has been embraced by the Chinese media, with millions of men crippling the country’s internet providers trying to find out how to get to the town. | df = }}</ref>
Claes Bertilson, spokesperson for Sweden's Association of Local Authorities and Regions, said: “At 25,000 residents, the town would be one of the largest in northern Sweden, and I find it hard to believe that you could keep something like that a secret for more than 150 years.”<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/6280464/Women-only-town-of-Swedish-lesbians-does-not-exist.html "Women-only town of Swedish lesbians 'does not exist'" ''Telegraph.co.uk'' 9 Oct 09]</ref>
== See also == * [[Noiva do Cordeiro]]

{{For|a homonymous ''Daily Telegraph'' Affair|Religious views on smoking#Christianity}} The '''Daily Telegraph Affair''' was the uproar that followed the 28 October 1908 publication in British newspaper ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' of comments by [[German Emperor|German Kaiser]] [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]] intended to improve [[Germany–United Kingdom relations|German-British relations]]. It was a major diplomatic blunder that worsened relations and badly hurt the Kaiser's reputation; after that he played a much smaller role in deciding foreign policy. The episode had a far greater impact in Germany than overseas.Christopher M. Clark, ''Kaiser Wilhelm II'' (2000) pp. 172-80.{{cite book|author=John C. G. Röhl|title=Wilhelm II: Into the Abyss of War and Exile, 1900–1941|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FN9GAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA662|year=2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|pages=662–95}}Lamar Cecil, ''Wilhelm II: Emperor and Exile, 1900–1941'' (1996) vol. 2, pp. 123-45. ''The Telegraph'' presented what appeared to be an interview with the Kaiser. It was in fact the reworked notes by [[British Army]] officer [[Edward Montagu-Stuart-Wortley]] of conversations he had with Wilhelm II in 1907.{{cite book |last=MacMillan|first=Margaret |author-link=Margaret MacMillan |title=The War That Ended Peace: The Road to 1914 |chapter=Ch 5. Dreadnought: The Anglo-German Naval Rivalry |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |year=2013 |isbn=978-0812994704 | edition=Kindle| ref=harv}} The ''Telegraph'' sent the "interview" to Wilhelm II for approval, who in turn passed it to [[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Bernhard von Bülow]], who later stated that he was too busy to edit the document, though Bülow's critics charged that he did not wish to challenge the Kaiser. Instead Bülow passed it on to the [[Federal Foreign Office|Foreign Ministry]] for their review, which apparently did not happen. It included wild statements and diplomatically damaging remarks, the most infamous of which was
You English are [[Mad as a March hare|mad, mad, mad as March hares]]. What has come over you that you are so completely given over to suspicions quite unworthy of a great nation?The World War One Document Archive. The Daily Telegraph Affair , https://wwi.lib.byu.edu/index.php/The_Daily_Telegraph_Affair, quoted in Ham, p.148-9
Wilhelm had seen the interview as an opportunity to promote his views and ideas on Anglo-German friendship, but due to his emotional outbursts during the course of the interview, he ended up further alienating not only the British, but also the French, Russians, and Japanese.Thomas G. Otte, "‘An altogether unfortunate affair’: Great Britain and the daily telegraph affair." ''Diplomacy and Statecraft'' 5#2 (1994): 296-333. He implied, among other things, that the Germans cared nothing for the British; that the French and Russians had attempted to incite Germany to intervene in the [[Second Boer War]]; and that the German naval buildup was targeted against the Japanese, not Britain.[http://wwi.lib.byu.edu/index.php/The_Daily_Telegraph_Affair partial text of "The interview of the Emperor Wilhelm II on October 28, 1908"] The British leadership had already decided that Wilhelm was somewhat mentally disturbed, and saw this as further evidence of his unstable personality, as opposed to an indication of official German hostility.Thomas G. Otte, "'The Winston of Germany': The British Foreign Policy Élite and the Last German Emperor." ''Canadian Journal of History ''36.3 (2001): 471-504. The ''Daily Telegraph'' crisis deeply wounded Wilhelm's previously unimpaired self-confidence, and he soon suffered a severe bout of depression from which he never fully recovered. He lost much of the influence he had previously exercised in domestic and foreign policy.Cecil, ''Wilhelm II: Emperor and Exile, 1900–1941'' (1996) vol. 2, pp. 138–41 The effect in Germany was quite significant; severe embarrassment was followed by serious calls for the Kaiser's abdication. The conservative Junker politician [[Elard von Oldenburg-Januschau]] was the only member of the Reichstag to defend the Kaiser throughout the Affair. Wilhelm kept a very low profile for many months after the ''Daily Telegraph'' fiasco, slumping into a deep depression, never fully recovering from the humiliation. He later exacted his revenge by forcing the resignation of the Chancellor Bülow{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}, who had abandoned the Emperor to public scorn by not having the transcript edited before its German publication.Lamar Cecil, ''Wilhelm II: Emperor and Exile, 1900–1941'' (1996) vol. 2, pp. 135–7, 143–45Donald E. Shepardson, "The 'Daily Telegraph' Affair," ''Midwest Quarterly'' (1980) 21#2 pp 207–220 Bülow recalled in his Memoirs that: :A dark foreboding ran through many Germans that such... stupid, even puerile speech and action on the part of the Supreme Head of State could lead to only one thing - catastrophe.{{cite book|author=Bernhard Bülow (Fürst von)|title=Memoirs of Prince Von Bülow vol 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uFYmAQAAMAAJ|year=1972|publisher=AMS Press|page=396}} == Notes == {{Reflist}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Daily Telegraph'' Affair}} ==Further reading== * Cecil, Lamar. ''Wilhelm II. Vol. II: Emperor and Exile, 1900-1941'' (1996), pp 123–45. [https://www.questia.com/library/105767341/wilhelm-ii online] * Clark, Christopher M. ''Kaiser Wilhelm II'' (2000) pp. 172–80. * Cole, Terence F. "The Daily Telegraph Affair and its Aftermath: The Kaiser, Bülow and the Reichstag, 1908–1909." in by John C. G. Röhl and Nicolaus Sombart, eds. ''Kaiser Wilhelm II: New Interpretations. The Corfu Papers'' (Cambridge UP, 1982). * Lerman, Katharine A. ''The Chancellor as Courtier: Bernhard Von Bulow and the Governance of Germany, 1900-1909'' (2003). * Otte, Thomas G. "‘An altogether unfortunate affair’: Great Britain and the daily telegraph affair." ''Diplomacy and Statecraft'' 5#2 (1994): 296-333. * Otte, Thomas G. "'The Winston of Germany': The British Foreign Policy Élite and the Last German Emperor." ''Canadian Journal of History ''36.3 (2001): 471-504. {{DEFAULTSORT:Scandal, The Daily Telegraph}} [[Category:Wilhelm II, German Emperor]] [[Category:Germany–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:Germany–Japan relations]] [[Category:Germany–Russia relations]] [[Category:France–Germany relations]] [[Category:1908 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1908 in Germany]] [[Category:1908 controversies]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''David Bek''''' ({{lang-hy|Դավիթ Բեկ}}; {{lang-ru|Давид Бек}}) is an opera composed by [[Armen Tigranian]] based on the [[Raffi (novelist)|Raffi]] novel ''David Bek'' (1880–82). After the composer's death, the opera was completed by Levon Khoja-Eynatov, G. Budaghyan, and the [[libretto]] was developed by A. Ter-Hovhannisyan.<ref>Энциклопедический музыкальный словарь, Москва 1966</ref>
The opera describes events surrounding the historical figure of [[David Bek]] in the early 18th century and the struggle of the [[Armenian people]] against [[Persia]].
''David Bek'' was first performed in [[Yerevan]] in 1950.
==References== <references />
{{Opera-stub}}
