revision.text:
The '''International Charter "Space and Major Disasters"''' is a non-binding [[charter]] which provides for the [[charity (practice)|charitable]] and [[humanitarian]] retasked acquisition of and transmission of space [[artificial satellite|satellite]] data to relief organizations in the event of major disasters. Initiated by the [[European Space Agency]] and the French space agency [[CNES]] after the [[United Nations Conference on the Exploration and Peaceful Uses of Outer Space|UNISPACE III]] conference held in Vienna, [[Austria]] in July 1999, it officially came into operation on November 1, 2000 after the [[Canadian Space Agency]] signed onto the charter on October 20, 2000. Their space assets were then, respectively, [[European Remote-Sensing Satellite|ERS]] and [[ENVISAT]], [[SPOT (satellites)|SPOT]] and [[Formosat]], and [[RADARSAT]].
The assorted satellite assets of various corporate, national, and international [[space agency|space agencies]] and entities provide for humanitarian coverage which is wide albeit contingent. First activated for floods in northeast France in December 2001,<ref>[http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-014 Disaster Charter – Activation Details]. Disasterscharter.org. Retrieved on 2011-03-13.</ref> the Charter has since brought space assets into play for numerous floods, earthquakes, oil spills, forest fires, tsunamis, major snowfalls, volcanic eruptions, hurricanes and landslides,<ref>[http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activations Disaster Charter – Recent Activations]. Disasterscharter.org (2010-05-28). Retrieved on 2011-03-13.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Saving lives from space|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19826963|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> and furthermore (and unusually) for the search for [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]]<ref name="dis482">http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-482</ref> and for the [[2014 West Africa Ebola outbreak]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-29577175%20/world-africa-29577175 /world-africa-29577175]</ref> As of 2015, fifteen space agencies are signatories; dozens of satellites are available with [[image resolution]]s ranging from {{convert|8|km|mi|0}} per pixel to about {{convert|0.3|m|ft|0}} per pixel.<ref name="15 Space Agencies">{{cite web | url=https://www.disasterscharter.org/documents/10180/14458/International-Charter-Newsletter-Issue-12-Jan-2016 | title=15 Years of International Cooperation on Disaster Response | publisher=International Charter Space and Major Disasters | work=International Charter Newsletter | date=2015-12-31 | accessdate=2016-05-07 | pages=5}}</ref> As of August 2018, it had had 579 activations, from 125 countries, and had 17 members, which contributed 34 satellites.<ref name="ICOS&MD pdate">{{Cite web |url=https://disasterscharter.org/web/guest/about-the-charter |title=Charter in Numbers |last=n/a |first=n/a |date=2018-08-07 |website=International Charter on Space and Major Disasters |access-date=2018-08-07}}</ref> It won the prestigious Pecora award in 2017. <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/international-charter-wins-prestigious-pecora-award?redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fdisasterscharter.org%2Fweb%2Fguest%2Fhome%3Fp_p_id%3D101_INSTANCE_c42X4nVrhK5U%26p_p_lifecycle%3D0%26p_p_state%3Dnormal%26p_p_mode%3Dview%26p_p_col_id%3Dcolumn-1%26p_p_col_pos%3D2%26p_p_col_count%3D3 |title=International Charter wins prestigious Pecora Award |date=2017-11-22 |website=International Charter on Space and Major Disasters |access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref>
==Successive signatories and satellite assets== * The United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration ([[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]) — ([[POES]]), ([[GOES]]) and Indian Space Research Organization ([[ISRO]]) (September 2001)<ref name="Charter History by usgs"/> — (the Indian Remote Sensing satellite series) * Argentine Space Agency ([[CONAE]]) (July 2003)<ref name="Charter History by usgs"/> — ([[SAC-C]]) * February 2005 – Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency ([[JAXA]])<ref name="Charter History by usgs">[https://www.gwu.edu/~spi/assets/docs/Ryan%20-%20International%20Charter%20Space%20and%20Major%20Disasters.pdf International Charter on Space and Major Disasters] // International Symposium on Remote Sensing Applications to Natural Hazards, Washington, D.C. 12 September 2007, Barbara J. Ryan (Associate Director for Geography, U. S. Geological Survey)</ref> — ([[ALOS]]) * ? 2005 – United States Geological Survey ([[USGS]]) as part of the U.S. team — ([[Landsat]], [[Quickbird]], [[GeoEye 1]]) * November 2005 – The British space agency [[British National Space Centre|BNSC]] ([[UK-DMC]]) with the company [[DMCii]] * May 2007 – China National Space Administration ([[CNSA]]) — (the FY, SJ, ZY satellite series) * ? – [[DMC International Imaging]] * ? – The Algerian space agency Centre National des Techniques Spatiales — ([[ALSAT-1]]) * ? – The Nigerian [[National Space Research and Development Agency]] — (NigeriaSat) * ? – The Turkish space agency [[TUBITAK]] — ([[BILSAT-1]]) * ? – The British company BNSC/Surrey Satellite Technology Limited — ([[UK-DMC]]) * ? – The British company BNSC/Qinetiq — ([[Top Sat]]) * 2012 German Aerospace Center ([[German Aerospace Center|DLR]]) - ([[TerraSAR-X]], [[TanDEM-X]]) * 2012 Korea Aerospace Research Institute ([[KARI]]) - (Arirang 3, 3A, 5) * 2012 Instituto Nacional de PesquisasEspaciais, Brazil ([[National Institute for Space Research|INPE]]) * 2012 European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites ([[EUMETSAT]])<ref name="disasterscharter.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.disasterscharter.org/c/document_library/get_file?p_l_id=23109&folderId=172718&name=DLFE-4704.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111231659/http://www.disasterscharter.org/c/document_library/get_file?p_l_id=23109&folderId=172718&name=DLFE-4704.pdf |archivedate=2013-11-11 |df= }}</ref> * 2013 [[Russian Space Agency]]<ref>[http://www.astrowatch.net/2014/04/roscosmos-acknowledged-full-member-of.html Roscosmos Acknowledged Full Member of International Charter on Space and Major Disasters] // APRIL 23, 2014</ref> ([[Resurs-DK No.1]], [[Resurs-P No.1]], [[Kanopus-V]], Meteor-M1)<ref>[http://geomatica.ru/pdf/2013_03/2013_14-16.pdf Роскосмос — 15-й участник Международной хартии по космосу и крупным катастрофам] (Russian space agency is 15th member of International Charter on Space and Major Disasters) // ГЕОМАТИКА. — 2013. — № 3. — С. 14-16. ([http://geomatica.ru/eng/article.html GEOMATIKA] 2013 №3 pages 14-16) {{ru icon}}</ref> * 2016 ([[Bolivarian Agency for Space Activities]]) (ABAE) - ([[VRSS-1]])
As of 2012 the live satellites and their instrumentalities were: The high resolution and very high resolution radar sensors of [[ENVISAT]] (decommissioned in April), [[RISAT-1]], [[RADARSAT]]-1 & 2, [[TerraSAR-X]] and [[TanDEM-X]]; the high resolution and very high resolution optical sensors of [[SPOT (satellite)|SPOT satellites]]4 & 5, [[Pleiades (satellite)|Pleiades]], [[Landsat]] 5 & 7, [[PROBA]]1, [[UK-DMC 2]], [[KOMPSAT-2]], [[Indian Remote Sensing|IRS-P5]], [[Resourcesat-2]], [[Oceansat-2]], [[Cartosat-2]], [[IMS-1]], and [[RapidEye]]; the medium and low resolution optical sensors of [[POES]], [[GOES]], and [[Comisión Nacional de Actividades Espaciales|SAC-C]]. Furthermore, specific agreements with other entities, including corporations, allow the Charter access to additional products of high and very high resolution from satellites such as the [[Formosat]] series, [[GeoEye]], [[IKONOS]], [[QuickBird]], and [[WorldView]].<ref name="disasterscharter.org"/>
In 2014 the charter was activated 41 times for disasters in 30 countries. In that year the live satellites and their instrumentalities included: The high and very high resolution [[radar]] sensors of Risat-1, [[RADARSAT]]-2, [[TerraSAR-X]], and [[TanDEM-X]] and [[Sentinel-1A]]; the optical high and very high resolution sensors of [[UK-DMC]] 2, [[Landsat]] 7 and 8, [[SPOT (satellite)|SPOT]] series 5, 6, and 7, [[Pleiades (satellite)|Pléiades]] 1A and 1B, [[PROBA]] 1, SJ-9A, GF-1, [[KOMPSAT-2]], IRS-P5 ([[Cartosat]]-1), Cartosat-2, [[Resourcesat-2]], [[Oceansat-2]], [[RapidEye]], [[Kanopus]]-V, and [[Resurs-P]], and the [[HDTV]] camera mounted the [[Kibo (ISS module)|Kibo]] module of the [[International Space Station]]; and the medium and low optical sensors of [[POES]], [[GOES]], FY-3C, the [[Metop]] series, the first two [[Meteosat]] generations, and [[Meteor-M]]. Specific agreements with other entities allow for the usage of the [[Formosat]], [[GeoEye]], [[IKONOS]], [[QuickBird]], and [[WorldViews]] satellites, which have high and very high resolution. Archival data from defunct satellites such as [[ALOS]], [[ENVISAT]], [[European Remote-Sensing Satellite|ERS]], [[CBERS]], [[IRS-1C]], [[Astra 1D]], IRS P4, P6, [[IMS-1]], [[RADARSAT]]-1, SAC-C, SPOT 1-3 & 4, [[UK-DMC]], [[Landsat]]-5 and NigeriaSat are also available.<ref name="2014 Satellites and Instrumentalities">{{cite web | url=https://www.disasterscharter.org/documents/10180/66908/14thAnnualReport | title=14th Annual Report | publisher=International Charter Space & Major Disasters | date=2015-12-31 | accessdate=2016-05-07 | pages=4–6 }}</ref>
==Major events resulting in activation== This is very much a partial list; the 500th activation of the Charter was on 1 August 2016.<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/500th-activation-of-the-international-charter |title=500th activation of the International Charter |publisher=International Charter on Space and Major Disasters |date=1 August 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2016}}</ref> * 2004: The charter was activated for the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]] by the Indian Space Research Organisation ([[ISRO]]).<ref>http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-077</ref> * 14 January 2010: The French Civil Protection authorities, [[Public Safety Canada]], the American Earthquake Hazards Programme of [[USGS]] and the [[UN Stabilisation Mission in Haiti]] requested a post-event map of Haiti, two days after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]], via the Space and Major Disasters Charter.<ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/01/100114143323.htm ''First Satellite Map of Haiti Earthquake''], ScienceDaily</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/jonathanamos/2010/01/how-satellites-are-being-used.shtml Spaceman: How satellites are being used in Haiti]. BBC (2010-01-14). Retrieved on 2011-03-13.</ref> * 22 February 2011: Both COGIC (French Civil Protection)<ref>{{fr icon}} [[:fr:Plan Orsec|Plan Orsec – Wikipédia]]. Fr.wikipedia.org. Retrieved on 2011-03-13.</ref> and the American [[USGS]] requested the activation of the charter on the behalf of [[MCDEM]] New Zealand, thus readily providing satellite imagery for aid and rescue services following the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]].<ref>[http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-357 Disaster Charter – Earthquake in New Zealand]. Disasterscharter.org. Retrieved on 2011-03-13.</ref> * 12 March 2011: Japan, through its space agency [[JAXA]], requested the activation of the charter to help in managing the aftermath of [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]].<ref>[http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-359 Disaster Charter – Earthquake in Japan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002512/http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-359 |date=2011-03-16 }}. Disasterscharter.org (2010-05-28). Retrieved on 2011-03-13.</ref> * 8 November 2013: The charter was activated by Philippine authorities as super-typhoon [[Typhoon Haiyan (2013)|Haiyan]] made landfall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-466 |title=Disaster Charter - Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines |publisher=Disasterscharter.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref> * 11 March 2014: The charter was activated by Chinese authorities to aid in the search for [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]] which disappeared on March 8, 2014, en route from Kuala Lumpur International Airport to Beijing Capital International Airport.<ref name="dis482"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-57620246-1/15-space-organizations-join-hunt-for-missing-malaysian-jet/ |title=15 space organizations join hunt for missing Malaysian jet |work=CNET|accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref> * 9 October 2014: The charter was activated by the [[USGS]] on behalf of National Geospatial Agency to monitor the [[2014 West Africa Ebola outbreak]] (in [[2014 Ebola virus epidemic in Sierra Leone|Sierra Leone]], specifically), the first time its space assets have been used in an epidemiological role.<ref>[https://www.disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/other-in-sierra-leone Ebola epidemic in West Africa]</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-29577175|title=Global Ebola outbreak deaths exceed 4,000 - WHO |journal=BBC News |date=10 October 2014 |accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref> * 4 May 2016: [[Public Safety Canada]] activated the charter for the [[2016 Fort McMurray Wildfire|Fort McMurray Wildfire]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/fire-in-canada |title=Latest Activation: Fire in Canada |publisher=International Charter on Space and Major Disasters |date=4 May 2016 |accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> * 13 August 2016: The charter was activated by the USGS in response to the [[2016 Louisiana floods]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.disasterscharter.org/web/guest/activations/-/article/flood-in-united-stat-3 |title=Flood in United States |publisher=International Charter on Space and Major Disasters |date=14 August 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2016}}</ref> * 24 August 2017: The Charter was activated by the USGS for [[Hurricane Harvey]].<ref name="Satellite Coverage Activated for Hurricane Harvey ">{{Cite web |url=https://disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/cyclone-in-united-states-call-626-?redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fdisasterscharter.org%2Fweb%2Fguest%2Fhome%3Fp_p_id%3D101_INSTANCE_F1SeOJT57fTb%26p_p_lifecycle%3D0%26p_p_state%3Dnormal%26p_p_mode%3Dview%26p_p_col_id%3Dcolumn-1%26p_p_col_pos%3D2%26p_p_col_count%3D4 |title=Cyclone in the U.S. |date=2017-08-24 |website=International Charter Space & Major Disasters |access-date=2017-08-28}}</ref> *5 September 2017: The Charter was activated by the Comisión Nacional de Emergencias in the [[Dominican Republic]] for [[Hurricane Irma]];<ref name="Hurricane Irma">{{Cite web |url=https://disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/ocean-wave-in-dominican-republic-call-628-?redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fdisasterscharter.org%2Fweb%2Fguest%2Fhome%3Fp_p_id%3D101_INSTANCE_F1SeOJT57fTb%26p_p_lifecycle%3D0%26p_p_state%3Dnormal%26p_p_mode%3Dview%26p_p_col_id%3Dcolumn-1%26p_p_col_pos%3D2%26p_p_col_count%3D4 |title=Hurricane Irma in the Dominican Republic |date=2017-09-05 |website=International Charter Space & Major Disasters |access-date=2017-09-06}}</ref> Haiti and the United States followed suit shortly thereafter. <ref name="U.S. Activates International Charter on Space and Major Disasters">{{Cite web |url=https://disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/flood-in-united-states-call-629- |title=Hurricane Irma in the United States |date=2017-09-07 |website=International Charter Space and Major Disasters |access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/flood-in-haiti-call-630- |title=Irma in Haiti |date=2018-09-07 |website=International Charter Space & Major Disasters |access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref> *19 September 2017: The Charter was activated in the aftermath of [[2017 Central Mexico earthquake]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Tom |last=Parry |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/canada-satellite-hurricane-monitor-1.4299581 |title=Help from above: Canadian satellite assists with hurricane recovery, other natural disasters |publisher=CBC News |date=2017-09-22}}</ref> *20 September 2017. The Charter was activated by the Comisión Nacional de Emergencias CNE in the [[Dominican Republic]] for [[Hurricane Maria]].<ref name="Dominican Republic Activates the International Charter on Space and Major Disasters">{{Cite web |url=https://disasterscharter.org/web/guest/-/flood-in-dominican-republic-activation-556- |title=Hurricane Maria in the Dominican Republic |website=International Charter on Space and Major Disasters |access-date=2017-09-24}}</ref> *22 November 2017. The Charter was activated by the [[Comisión Nacional de Actividades Espaciales]] due to the [[Disappearance of ARA San Juan]].<ref name="conaearasanjuan">{{cite web|title=Tecnología Espacial para la Búsqueda del Submarino Argentino|url=http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/espanol/2017/954-tecnologia-espacial-para-la-busqueda-del-submarino-argentino|website=CONAE|accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight|Science|Information Technology|Disaster|International Relations}} * [[Footprint (satellite)]] * [[International Designator]] * [[List of Earth observation satellites]] * [[Satellite Catalog Number]] * [[Space exploration]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.disasterscharter.org/ Official site] *[https://www.disasterscharter.org/web/guest/text-of-the-charter Text of the charter]
{{DEFAULTSORT:International Charter On Space And Major Disasters}} [[Category:Space treaties]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1999]] [[Category:Treaties entered into force in 2000]] [[Category:Disaster management]] [[Category:Space photography and videography]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = ''Fête de l'Escalade'' |type = historical |longtype = |image = Escalade-battle-2.jpg |caption = L'Escalade celebrating the defeat of the surprise attack by troops sent by Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy |observedby = [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] |begins = |ends = |date = |date2015 = 11 December to 13 December |date2016 = 9 December to 11 December |celebrations = |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |observances = |relatedto = }}
'''''L'Escalade''''', or '''''Fête de l'Escalade''''' (from [[escalade]], the act of scaling defensive walls), was a notable attempt by [[Catholic]] [[Duchy of Savoy|Savoy]] to conquer [[Protestant]] [[Geneva]], now commemorated by an annual festival each December celebrating the defeat of the surprise attack by troops sent by [[Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy]] during the night of 11–12 December 1602. The celebrations and other commemorative activities are usually held on 12 December or the closest weekend.
After fending off the Savoyard attack, with the help of Swiss Protestant cities, Geneva joined the [[Swiss Confederation]].
==Background== For years, the duke coveted the wealth of the self-governing, independent, republican, Protestant city-state. When Charles Emmanuel came to the throne of the [[House of Savoy]] in 1580, he longed to make Geneva his capital north of the Alps and crush Protestantism. [[Pope Clement VIII]] offered encouragement; in 1602 he appointed as Catholic bishop of Geneva [[Francis de Sales]], an effective preacher who had recently been successful in re-Catholicizing the [[Chablais]] district of [[Savoy]] on the south side of Lake Geneva.
==Attack== [[File:Cequelaino.png|thumb|Music score of the Cé qu'è l'ainô]] [[File:Geneva Medal 1840 Commemoration of L'Escalade 1602, obverse.jpg|thumb|left|Geneva Medal 1840. Commemoration of L'Escalade 1602, obverse.]] [[File:Geneva Medal 1840 Commemoration of L'Escalade 1602, reverse.jpg|thumb|left|Geneva Medal 1840 Commemoration of L'Escalade 1602, reverse. It shows the 17 names of Genevois killed directly in the battle.]] On December 11 and December 12 ([[Old Style]]) 1602 — the darkest night of the year — the forces of the Duke of Savoy, under the command of the seigneur d'Albigny, and those of Charles Emmanuel's brother-in-law, [[Philip III of Spain]], launched an attack on the city-state of Geneva.<ref name = "Mercurius">Gaspare Lorchano, ''[[Mercurius Gallobelgicus]]'', vol. 4 (Cologne, Wilhelm Lutzenkirch, 1603), p. 465f. [https://books.google.com/books?id=if07AAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books]</ref> The troops marched along the [[Arve River]] at night and assembled at Plainpalais, just outside the walls of Geneva, at 2 o'clock in the morning. The original plan was to send in a group of commandos to open the city gate and let the other troops in. The Geneva citizens defeated the invaders by preventing them from scaling the wall using cannon fire, and by fighting in the streets against the few who managed to climb over (a climb in [[French language|French]] is an ''escalade''). The alarm was raised, the church bells were rung and the Genevese were alerted. The night guard Isaac Mercier succeeded in cutting the rope holding up the portcullis, thus foiling the plan to open the main city gate. The populace fought alongside their town militia and the duke's 2000-plus mercenaries were defeated. The Genevese lost 18 men in the fighting; the Savoyards suffered 54 fatalities and the troops had to retreat. Thirteen invaders who had been taken prisoner, including several well-born gentlemen, were summarily hanged the following day as brigands, since they could not be treated as prisoners of war, peace having been repeatedly sworn on the part of Savoy.<ref name = "Compagnie1602">[http://www.1602.ch/ Compagnie de 1602].</ref>
According to Genevese legend, Catherine Cheynel ("''Mère Royaume''"), originally from Lyon and the wife of Pierre Royaume, a mother of 14 children, seized a large cauldron of hot soup and poured it on the attackers. The Royaume family lived just above the La Monnaie town gate. The heavy cauldron of boiling soup landed on the head of a Savoyard attacker, killing him. The commotion that this caused also helped to rouse the townsfolk to defend the city.
After the defeat (and after a retaliation campaign by Geneva against Savoy, known as the contre-Escalade, that failed to meet its objectives), the Duke of Savoy accepted a lasting peace, sealed by the [[Treaty of St. Julien]] of July 12, 1603.
The story of L'Escalade is told in a song called "Cé qu'è l'ainô", written in a [[Franco-Provençal language|Franco-Provençal]] dialect around 1603 by an unknown author. The song has become the "national" [[anthem]] of Geneva; while the complete version comprises 68 stanzas, only four of them are usually sung.<ref>''Cé qu'è lainô'': National hymn of Geneva [http://un2sg4.unige.ch/athena/helvetia/cqlaino.html Lyrics and French translation]</ref>
It was also celebrated in verse by [[Samuel Chappuzeau]] in his "Genève Délivrée", the manuscript of which was presented to Geneva after his death in 1701.
==Celebration== {{unreferenced section|date=December 2016}} [[File:Commémoration de l'Escalade à Genève 05.jpg|thumb|upright|A soldier in the commemorative parade]] [[File:Marmite-Escalade.jpg|thumb|upright|left|A chocolate "marmite de l'Escalade"]] [[File:Marmite-Escalade-window.jpg|thumb|The window of a chocolate shop in [[Carouge]] selling marmites]]
Although the armed conflict actually took place after midnight, in the early morning on December 12, celebrations and other commemorative activities are usually held on December 11 or the closest weekend. Celebrations include a large ''marmite'' (cauldron) made of chocolate and filled with [[marzipan]] vegetables and candies wrapped in the Geneva colours of red and gold. It is customary for the eldest and youngest in the room to smash the ''marmite'', while reciting, "''Ainsi périrent les ennemis de la République!'' " (Thus perished the enemies of the Republic), referring to how Catherine Cheynel, better known as "''Mère Royaume''," poured boiling hot vegetable soup on soldiers climbing up the walls of the city. Other traditions include [[mulled wine]], a large serving of soup, and children in various types of costumes knocking on people's doors and singing Escalade songs for money. It is also common for children in school to prepare vegetable soup, which is served to parents and families that night. Teenagers tend to throw eggs, shaving cream, and flour at each other as part of the celebration. The high school students parade together by first going to "conquer" each other and end up in the central square of the old town after walking through the "rues basses" to the plaine de Plainpalais and back.<ref name = "l'Escalade Festival Tourist Information">[http://www.geneva.info/events/escalade/]</ref>
There is also a parade on Friday evening: the names of the eighteen who died—Jacques Billon finally died of his wounds a year later—are called out, one after another. The historical procession on Sunday features more or less 800 people (from old Genevese families) with historical costumes, the remaining fragments of the ladders used by the Savoyards, and horses. This parade - organised since 1926 by the [[Compagnie de 1602]] - attracts every year generally tens of thousand spectators.
==Escalade Run== Since 1978 there has been another element to the celebration of the Escalade, with a [[road running]] event being held the weekend of or preceding the night of the 11th (depending on whether or not the 11th falls on a weekend).<ref>http://www.worldcat.org/title/escalade-son-origine-et-ses-consequences/oclc/715050789</ref> The run traditionally starts in the ''[[park|parc]] des Bastions'' and goes through the Old City of Geneva, before finishing near the start again. It is one of the most significant annual events in Geneva.<ref>http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/multimedia/video/Fete_de_lEscalade.html?cid=28995618&itemId=28995606</ref> To partake in the Escalade race, people register and pay online or by mail. When registering, people have to specify which race they want to run. There are options for male races and female races for different age groups classified under year of birth and in some cases with which institution (for example with Ecolint at different grade levels). Besides the regular runs, there are three other major races: the Duke's race which is exclusive for adults and it costs 45 CHF, the Walking and Nordic Walking races for the ages of 10+ cost 27 CHF and the Marmite adults and youth races, in which participants wear costumes, which cost 26 CHF and 16 CHF respectively.<ref>http://www.escalade.ch/cms/index.php/en/categories-and-schedule</ref> In recent years, participants in the races started wearing group T-shirts and creative costumes to the run, thus making it a continuation of the parade. After each race the results are announced and the best results of each race get published in the Tribune de Genève.<ref>http://www.escalade.ch/cms/index.php/en/results</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.geneva.info/events/escalade/]
==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.1602.ch Compagnie de 1602], the group who organises the yearly festival. * [http://www.escalade.ch La Course de l'Escalade]. * [http://www.zum.de/whkmla/military/17cen/geneva1602.html World History at KMLA: The Savoyard attack on Geneva]. * [http://www.cosmopolis.ch/english/cosmo43/fete_de_l_escalade.htm Fête de l'Escalade]: a yearly celebration in Geneva in memory of the night attack by the Savoyards in 1602.
{{Coord missing|Switzerland}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Escalade}} [[Category:Conflicts in 1602]] [[Category:Battles involving Savoy]] [[Category:Culture in Geneva]] [[Category:History of Geneva]] [[Category:Festivals in Switzerland]] [[Category:December events]] [[Category:1602 in Europe]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Geneva]] [[Category:17th century in Switzerland]] [[Category:Winter events in Switzerland]]

revision.comment: fix duplicate ref def due to edits by [[User:SlimVirgin]]
revision.text:
'''Animals used by laboratories for testing purposes''' are largely supplied by dealers who specialize in selling them to universities, medical and veterinary schools, and companies that provide contract [[Animal testing|animal-testing]] services. It is comparatively rare that animals are procured from sources other than specialized dealers,<ref name=library>{{Cite web|url=http://www.libraryindex.com/pages/2183/Research-Animals-SOURCES-RESEARCH-ANIMALS.html|title=Sources of Research Animals|publisher=Library Index Science Encyclopedia|accessdate=April 12, 2010}}</ref> as this poses the threat of introducing disease into a colony and confounding any data collected.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aclam.org/education/guidelines/position_adequatecare.html|title=Adequate Veterinary Care Guidelines|publisher=American College of Laboratory Animal Medicine|accessdate=April 12, 2010}}</ref> However, suppliers of laboratory animals may include [[breeder]]s who supply purpose-bred animals, businesses that trade in wild animals, and dealers who supply animals sourced from pounds, auctions, and newspaper ads. Animal shelters may also supply the laboratories directly. Some animal dealers, termed Class B dealers, have been reported to engage in kidnapping pets from residences or illegally trapping strays, a practice dubbed as '''bunching'''.<ref name=bunching>Salinger, Lawrence and Teddlie, Patricia. [http://citation.allacademic.com/meta/p_mla_apa_research_citation/0/3/3/8/8/p33882_index.html "Paper presented at the annual meeting of the American Society of Criminology, Royal York, Toronto"], October 15, 2006.</ref><ref name=Gillham>Gillham, Christina. [http://www.newsweek.com/id/57139 "Bought to be sold"], ''Newsweek'', February 17, 2006.</ref><ref name=HSUSDealers>[http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/pets_experiments/ Class B dealers], Humane Society of the United States.</ref>
==Dealers in the United States== All laboratories using vertebrate lab animals in the United States are required by law to have a licensed veterinarian on staff and to adhere to the NIH Guide for the Use and Care of Laboratory Animals, which further stipulates that all protocols, including the sources for obtaining the animals, must be reviewed by an [[Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee|independent committee]].<ref>http://grants.nih.gov/grants/olaw/olaw.htm</ref>
===Class A dealers=== Class A breeders are licensed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to sell animals bred specifically for research.<ref>[http://a257.g.akamaitech.net/7/257/2422/14mar20010800/edocket.access.gpo.gov/cfr_2003/9cfr1.1.htm USDOA 9CFR1.1 Definitions]</ref> In July 2004, there were 4,117 licensed Class A dealers in the United States.<ref name=library/>
===Class B dealers=== Class B dealers are licensed by the USDA to buy animals from "random sources". This refers to animals who were not purpose-bred or raised on the dealers' property.<ref name=HSUSDealers/> Animals from "random sources" come from auctions, pounds, newspaper ads (including "free-to-home" ads), and some may be stolen pets or illegally trapped strays.<ref name=bunching/> As of February 2013, there were only seven active Class B dealers remaining in the United States. However, these sources round up "thousands" of cats and dogs each year for sale.<ref name=HSUSDealers/>
====Animal shelters==== Animals are also sold directly to laboratories by shelters. According to the [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] (ASPCA), Iowa, Minnesota, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Utah require publicly funded shelters to surrender animals to any Class B dealer who asks for them.<ref name=ASPCAdealers>[http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=kids_ri_animaltesting_comefrom Animal Testing: Where Do the Animals Come From?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080627163237/http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=kids_ri_animaltesting_comefrom |date=2008-06-27 }} ASPCA</ref> Fourteen states prohibit the practice,<ref>According to the ASPCA,{{cite web|url=http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename%3Dkids_ri_animaltesting_comefrom |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080627163237/http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=kids_ri_animaltesting_comefrom |archivedate=2008-06-27 |df= }} these states prohibit shelters from providing animals for research: Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Vermont, and West Virginia.</ref> and the remainder either have no relevant legislation, or permit the practice in certain circumstances.<ref name=ASPCAdealers/><ref name=HSUS1>[http://www.hsus.org/animals_in_research/species_used_in_research/dog.html Dog profile] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226113001/http://www.hsus.org/animals_in_research/species_used_in_research/dog.html |date=2008-02-26 }}, The Humane Society of the United States.</ref><ref>There is a discrepancy between the Humane Society and the ASPCA in the specific states requiring and prohibiting the practice; according to the former, 3 states require, while 17 states prohibit.</ref>
====Bunching==== According to a paper presented to the [[American Society of Criminology]] in 2006, an illegal economy in the theft of pets, mostly dogs, has emerged in the U.S. in recent years, with the thieves known as "bunchers". The bunchers sell the animals to Class B animal dealers, who pay $25 per animal. The dealers then sell the animals to universities, medical and veterinary schools, and companies providing animal-testing services. Lawrence Salinger and Patricia Teddlie of [[Arkansas State University]] told the conference that these institutions pay up to $500 for a stolen animal, who is often accompanied by forged documents and fake health certificates. Salinger and Teddlie argue that the stolen animals may affect research results, because they come from unknown backgrounds and have an uncertain health profile.<ref name=bunching/> Conversely the [[Foundation for Biomedical Research]] claim that pets being stolen for animal research is largely an [[Urban legend|urban myth]] and that the majority of stolen dogs are most likely used for [[dog fighting]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fbresearch.org/survivors/PetTheftMyth.htm|title=Foundation for Biomedical Research|work="The Pet Theft Myth|accessdate=2007-12-20}}</ref>
The largest Class B dealer in dogs in the U.S. was investigated for bunching by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) in 2005. Chester C. Baird, of Martin Creek Kennels and Pat's Pine Tree Farms in Willifore, [[Arkansas]], lost his licence after being convicted of 100 counts of animal abuse and neglect, and of stealing pets for laboratories and forging documentation. The criminal charges were filed after an eight-year investigation by an animal protection group, [[Last Chance for Animals]]. The group filmed over 72 hours of undercover video at Martin Creek Kennels, which included footage of dogs being shot.<ref>Crews, Chip, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/20/AR2006022001591.html ''HBO's 'Dogs': A Gnawing Portrait of Despair''], Washington Post, February 21, 2006</ref><ref name=HSUSBaird>[http://www.hsus.org/animals_in_research/animals_in_research_news/animal_dealer_loses_license_and_pays_record_fine.html Notorious Animal Dealer Loses License and Pays Record Fine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325225027/http://www.hsus.org/animals_in_research/animals_in_research_news/animal_dealer_loses_license_and_pays_record_fine.html |date=2008-03-25 }}, The Humane Society of the United States.</ref> In 2006, [[HBO]] produced '''''Dealing Dogs''''', a documentary film based on this footage.<ref>[http://www.hbo.com/docs/programs/dealingdogs/synopsis.html ''Dealing Dogs''], [[HBO]] Documentary</ref><ref>Lee, Felicia R., [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/21/arts/television/21dogs.html?pagewanted=all ''How Dogs Are Abused in a Scheme for Profit''], [[The New York Times]], February 21, 2006</ref>
Baird's customers included the [[University of Missouri]], [[University of Colorado Health Sciences Center]], and [[Oregon State University]]. According to the Humane Society of the United States, Missouri was experiencing such a high rate of pet theft that animal protection groups had dubbed it the "Steal Me State". In a 2008 article, Last Chance for Animals estimated that around two million pets are stolen in the U.S. each year.<ref name=HSUSBaird/>
==Dealers in the European Union == Animal dealers in the [[European Union]] (EU) are governed by Council Directive 86/609/EEC.<ref name=direct1>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31986L0609:EN:HTML Council Directive 86/609/EEC of 24 November 1986]</ref> This directive sets forth specific requirements regulating the supply and breeding of animals intended for use by testing facilities within the EU. The directive defines 'breeding establishment' as a facility engaged in breeding animals for their use in experiments, and 'supplying establishment' as a facility other than a breeding establishment, which supplies animals for experiments.
Article 15 of the directive requires supplying establishments to obtain animals only from approved breeding or other supplying establishments, "unless the animal has been lawfully imported and is not a feral or stray animal." Nonetheless, the directive allows exemptions from this sourcing requirement "under arrangements determined by the authority."<ref name=direct1/>
Animal rights supporters have raised concerns that these rules allow strays and pets to be used for experimentation, either by exemptions or by importing animals from non-EU countries, where the rules may be more lax.<ref>Langley, Chris et al. [http://www.experimentation-animale.org/english/gbchiens_chats_ch3.html ''Experiments on cats and dogs in France''], One Voice, France, March 2003</ref>
In 2010, a new EU directive was published on the protection of animals used for scientific purposes, repealing the old directive 86/609/EEC on January 1, 2013, with the exception of Article 13 (statistical information on the use of animals in experiments) which has been repealed on May 10, 2013.<ref>http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2010:276:0033:0079:EN:PDF</ref>
==See also== *[[American Association for Laboratory Animal Science]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{atestingend}} {{Animal rights|state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Animal testing]] [[Category:Animal rights]] [[Category:Cruelty to animals]]

web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2014/08/lesotho-military-attempted-coup-201483071742178598.html|title=Military coup under way in Lesotho|website=Al-Jazeera|date=30 August 2014|accessdate=12 September 2014}} |- style="background:#e6e9ff;" | [[2014 Gambian coup d'état attempt]] || 30 December || Attempt || {{flag|Gambia}} || Lieutenant Colonel Lamin Sanneh|| President [[Yahya Jammeh]] || || {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/31/world/africa/banjul-gambia.html?ref=world&_r=1|title=U.S. Embassy Describes Coup Attempt in Gambia|website=The New York Times|date=30 December 2014|accessdate=31 December 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-30642157|title=Yayha Jammeh: Gambia president 'home after coup plot'|website=BBC News|date=31 December 2014|accessdate=31 December 2014}} |- style="background:#ccf;" | [[2015 Burundian coup d'état attempt]] || 13 May || Attempt || {{flag|Burundi}} || General [[Godefroid Niyombare]] || President [[Pierre Nkurunziza]] || Three coup leaders arrested whilst Niyombare remains on the run. || {{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-32755709|title=Burundi President Pierre Nkurunziza returns to Bujumbura|website=BBC News|date=15 May 2015|accessdate=15 May 2015}} |- style="background:#e6e9ff;" | [[2015 Burkinabé coup d'état]] || 17 September || Attempt || {{flag|Burkina Faso}} || General [[Gilbert Diendéré]] || President [[Michel Kafando]] || Coup fails and the [[Regiment of Presidential Security]] is dissolved. || {{cite news|title=Soldiers crush protests as military seizes power in Burkina Faso |url=https://news.yahoo.com/burkina-faso-military-says-takes-power-dissolves-government-090705810.html |accessdate=17 September 2015|publisher=Reuters|date=17 September 2015}}Brahima Ouedraogo, [https://news.yahoo.com/burkina-faso-military-says-troops-trying-disarm-junta-153647446.html "Burkina Faso coup leader says he will hand back power"], Associated Press, 21 September 2015.{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2015/09/25/burkina-army-idINKCN0RP2CB20150925|title=Burkina Faso government disbands elite unit behind coup|publisher=Reuters|date=26 September 2015|accessdate=25 September 2015}} |- style="background:#ccf;" | [[2016 Burkinabé coup d'état attempt]] || 8 October || Attempt || {{flag|Burkina says|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-burkina-plot-idUSKCN12L248|website=Reuters}}{{cite web|title=Au Burkina Faso, le pouvoir affirme avoir déjoué une tentative de coup d’Etat|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2016/10/21/au-burkina-faso-le-pouvoir-affirme-avoir-dejoue-une-tentative-de-coup-d-etat_5018252_3212.html|website=Le Monde}} |- style="background:#e6e9ff;" | [[2016 Libyan coup d'état attempt]] || 14 October – ''Present'' || Ongoing || {{flag|Libya}} || Prime Minister [[Khalifa al-Ghawil]]
(claimed) || Prime Minister [[Fayez al-Sarraj]]
(claimed) || ||{{cite web|title=Rump of GNC and Ghwell stage coup, declaring themselves back in power|url=https://www.libyaherald.com/2016/10/14/gnc-and-ghwell-stage-coup-declaring-themselves-back-in-powe/|website=libyaherald}} |- style="background:#ccf;" | [[2016–2017 Gambian constitutional crisis]] || 9 December 2016 – 21 January 2017 || Attempt || {{flag|Gambia}} || [[Government of Gambia]] || President [[Yahya Jammeh]] || The dispute President [[Yahya Jammeh]] surrendered presidential duties in favour of Barrow and left the country to exile in Equatorial Guinea after two days after his Presidency deadline. ||{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/gambia-yahya-jammeh-agrees-step-170120184330091.html|title=Gambia's Yahya Jammeh confirms he will step down|website=Al-Jazeera|date=21 January 2017|accessdate=20 January 2017}} |- style="background:#e6e9ff;" |[[2017 Zimbabwean coup d'état]] || 14 – 21 November || Coup || {{flag|Zimbabwe}} || Zimbabwe defence forces under Major General [[Constantino Chiwenga]] || President [[Robert Mugabe]] || After military movements are seen and explosions heard in government districts in northern Harare, the ZDF takes over state television and says that President Mugabe is in its custody, but denies mounting a coup. On 21 November, the coup ended with the resignation of Robert Mugabe. || {{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/live/world-africa-41994362|title=Zimbabwe army takes on Mugabe - as it happened|last=Olewe|first=Dickens|date=November 15, 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=November 17, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Chothia|first2=Farouk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-42071488|title=Zimbabwe's President Mugabe resigns|date=21 November 2017|website=Bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 November 2017}} |- style="background:#ccf;" | 2017 Equatoguinean coup d'état attempt || 27 – 28 December 2017 || Attempt || {{flag|Equatorial Guinea}} || Unknown || President [[Francisco Macías Nguema]] || || {{cite news|url=http://www.cameroonintelligencereport.com/cameroon-equatorial-guinea-reopen-border-after-four-months/|title=Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea reopen border after four months|website=Cameroon Intelligence Report|date=23 April 2018|accessdate=24 April 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/84461/equatorial-guinea-heavy-clashes-reported-near-ebibeyin-jan-3-update-2|title=Equatorial Guinea: Heavy clashes reported near Ebibeyin Jan. 3 /update 2|website=Garda World|date=5 January 2018|accessdate=27 July 2018}} |} [[File:A tank in harare during the coup.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A tank in downtown [[Harare]]]] === Asia === [[File:2014_0526_Thailand_coup_Chang_Phueak_Gate_Chiang_Mai_02.jpg|thumb|Thai soldiers at the Chang Phueak Gate in Chiang Mai.]] {| style="background:#fff;" class="sortable wikitable" ! Coup resulted in [[Yemeni Civil War (2015)]] || {{cite news|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-feuding-parties-agree-transitional-council-150220065456873.html|title=Yemen feuding parties gaining control of the government. || {{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/turkish-prime-minister-reports-coup-attempt-1468613584|title=Turkish Prime Minister Reports Coup Attempt|date=15 July 2016|website=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 July 2016}}{{cite web|title=Turkish premier: Country under full government control after coup attempt|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/world/wp/2016/07/16/turkish-premier-country-under-full-government-control-after-coup-attempt/|website=Washington Post}} |- style="background:#ccf;" | against President [[Rodrigo Duterte]] by Filipino-Americans living in New York City. || {{cite news|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/09/20/malacanang-andanar-duterte-coup-plot.html|title = Ref(s) |- style="background:#ccf;" || [[2010 Ecuador crisis]] || 30 September || Attempt || {{flag|Ecuador}} || Unknown || President [[Rafael Correa]] || President Correa was attacked, then temporarily trapped in a hospital in what the secretary-general of the [[Organization of American States]] called "a coup d'etat in the making". He was later rescued by loyal troops. || {{cite news|author1=Hugh Bronstein|author2=Alexandra Valencia|title=Ecuador's Correa asserts control as police chief quits|publisher=Reuters|date=1 October 2010|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/10/01/us-ecuador-correa-idUSTRE68T40I20101001|accessdate=5 October 2010}}{{cite news|author=Tatiana Coba|title=Protesting police throw Ecuador into chaos|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Yahoo! Supreme Court assumes control of legislative powers. || {{cite web|title=Venezuela Muzzles Legislature, Moving Closer to One-Man Rule|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/30/world/americas/venezuelas-supreme-court-takes-power-from-legislature.html?_r=1|website=NYTimes}} ||{{cite web|title=Democracy in Latin America: A coup in Venezuela|url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2017/03/31/inenglish/1490956479_493684.html|website=bbc}} |- style="background:#ccf;" | [[2017 Venezuelan coup d'état attempt]] || 8 August || Attempt || {{flag|Venezuela}} || Unknown || President [[Nicolas Maduro]] || ||http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/ausland/venezuela-putsch-gegen-maduro-laut-regierung-niedergeschlagen-15139281.htmlhttp://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/venezuela-soldaten-rufen-zu-putsch-auf-mehrere-festnahmen-a-1161569.htmlhttp://www.n-tv.de/politik/Soldaten-rufen-zu-Putsch-auf-article19970593.htmlhttps://deutsch.rt.com/newsticker/55265-militaerrebellion-in-venezuela/ |} == See also == * [[Coup d'état]] * [[List of coups d'état and coup attempts by country]] * [[List of revolutions and rebellions]] (chronological listing) == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.jonathanmpowell.com/coup-detat-dataset.html Coups in the World, 1950-Present] - Database on coups and coup attempts 1950–present, by Jonathan Powell and Clayton Thyne. * [http://www.systemicpeace.org/inscrdata.html Coups d'Etat, 1946-2013] - List of coups and coup attempts 1946-2013, by the Center for Systemic peace. {{Coup d'état}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coups Detat And Coup Attempts Since 2010}} [[Category:2010s coups d'état and coup attempts|*]] [[Category:Coups d'état|*]] [[Category:History-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of military conflicts]] [[Category:2010s politics-related lists]]

page.title: List of events held in Štark Arena

revision.text:
This is the list of events held and announced to be held in the '''[[Belgrade Arena|Štark Arena]]'''.{{Cref2|a}} ==Past events== {| class="infobox bordered" |- |width=50px bgcolor="#CEF2E0"| ||Musical events |- |width=50px bgcolor="#F2E0CE"| ||Sporting events |- |width=50px bgcolor="#E0CEF2"| ||Political rallies |- |width=50px bgcolor="#F2CEE0"| ||Theatrical performances |- |width=50px bgcolor="#CEE0F2"| ||Conferences and fairs |- |width=50px | ||Other events |} [[File:SCG - USA - USA training.jpg|250px|thumb|right| August 6, 2004: The warm-up for the basketball friendly match between [[Serbia and Montenegro national basketball team|Serbia and Montenegro]] and [[United States men's national basketball team|United States]].]] [[File:BGArena4.jpg|250px|thumb|right| July 10, 2005: The [[FIVB World League 2005|2005]] [[FIVB World League|Volleyball FIVB World League]] final match between [[Serbia men's national volleyball team|Serbia and Montenegro]] and [[Brazil men's national volleyball team|Brazil]] is the first sold out event in the Belgrade Arena, with 18,140 people attending the match. The lower capacity of the Arena was caused by the removal of the seats on Level 100 East and Level 100 West.]] [[File:Greece-Germanypicture1291pw.jpg|250px|thumb|right| 22 – 25 September 2005: The elimination round of the [[Eurobasket 2005]] is held in the Arena, with [[Greece national basketball team|Greece]] becoming the European champions.]] [[File:Russia in the 2008 Eurovision Song Contest.jpg|250px|thumb|right| 20 – 24 May 2008: The [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008]] is held in the Arena, with [[Russia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2008|Russia's]] [[Dima Bilan]] winning among 43 participating countries' acts.]] [[File:Arena Srb-Fin.jpg|thumb|250px|right| August - September, 2008: Four [[Serbia national basketball team|Serbia national team]] [[EuroBasket 2009]] [[EuroBasket 2009 qualification|qualifying matches]] have been played at the Arena. The attendance at these matches is between 14,000 and 18,000, which sets up the record of the qualifications.]] [[File:Arena111.jpg|thumb|250px|right| March 5, 2009: The attendance of 22,567 at the basketball match between [[KK Partizan|Partizan]] and [[Panathinaikos BC|Panathinaikos]] sets an all-time record for the [[Euroleague]].]] [[File:Nemanja-bjelica-universiade-2009-beograd-atipiks.jpg|thumb|250px|right| 1 – 12 July 2009: [[Opening ceremony|Opening]] and closing ceremonies, as well as the [[Basketball at the 2009 Summer Universiade|basketball tournament]] at the [[2009 Summer Universiade]] are held at the Arena.]] [[File:Srb,Brz,Arena.jpg|thumb|250px|right| July 26, 2009: The attendance of 22,680 at the final match of the [[FIVB World League 2009|2009]] [[FIVB World League|Volleyball FIVB World League]] between [[Serbia men's national volleyball team|Serbia]] and [[Brazil men's national volleyball team|Brazil]] was the highest one for a sporting venue in the Arena at the time.]] [[File:Brazil - World League 2009.jpg|thumb|250px|right| July 26, 2009: [[Brazil men's national volleyball team|Brazil]] wins the [[FIVB World League 2009|2009]] [[FIVB World League|Volleyball FIVB World League]].]] [[File:Boracorba.jpg|thumb|250px|right| October 31, 2009: Serbian rock band [[Riblja Čorba]] holds a concert in the Arena.]] [[File:Ziki Nole DC10 C.jpg|thumb|250px|right| 17 – 19 September 2010: [[Serbia Davis Cup team|Serbia]] reaches the [[2010 Davis Cup]] [[2010 Davis Cup World Group|World Group]] finals with a 3–2 semifinal win against [[Czech Republic Davis Cup team|Czech Republic]].]] [[File:BrenaArena.jpg|thumb|250px|right| 20 – 21 October 2011: Yugoslav{{cite web|url=http://www.index.hr/xmag/clanak/lepa-brena-nisam-ni-hrvatica-ni-srpkinja-ja-sam-jugoslavenka/412754.aspx|title=Lepa Brena: Nisam ni Hrvatica ni Srpkinja, ja sam Jugoslavenka|publisher=index.hr|date=December 2008|accessdate=9 July 2013}} pop-folk singer [[Lepa Brena]] holds two consecutive concerts in the Arena.]] [[File:Mascot Tasa with Macedonian fan.JPG|thumb|250px|right| 21 – 29 January 2012: Main round and knockout stage of the [[2012 European Men's Handball Championship]] have been held in the Arena.]] [[File:Serbia Russia basketball friendly 20130812.jpg|thumb|250px|right| August 12, 2013: [[Serbia national basketball team|Serbia]] vs. [[Russia national basketball team|Russia]], [[Eurobasket 2013]] preparation match.]] [[File:Delije_EL.jpg|thumb|250px|right| October 17, 2013: [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena zvezda]] vs. [[PBC Lokomotiv Kuban|Lokomotiv Kuban]], [[2013–14 Euroleague|Euroleague 2013–14]] [[Euroleague 2013–14 Regular Season Group D|Regular Season Group D]] match. The first Crvena zvezda Euroleague match in the Arena.]] [[File:ZvezdaOly.jpg|thumb|250px|right| November 7, 2014: [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena zvezda]] vs. [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]], [[2014–15 Euroleague|Euroleague 2014–15]] [[2014–15 Euroleague Regular Season Group D|Regular Season Group D]] match.]] [[File:ZvezdaGalata2015.jpg|thumb|250px|right| January 16, 2015: [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena zvezda]] vs. [[Galatasaray S.K. (men's basketball)|Galatasaray]], [[2014–15 Euroleague|Euroleague 2014–15]] [[Euroleague 2014-15 Top 16 Group E|Top 16 Group E]] match.]] [[File:2016 European Water Polo Championship - Day 1 (Portugal - Greece).jpg|thumb|250px|right| 10 – 23 January 2016: Main round and knockout stage of the 2016 [[2016 Men's European Water Polo Championship|Men's]] and [[2016 Women's European Water Polo Championship|Women's]] [[European Water Polo Championship]]s have been held in the Arena. The first time a water polo pool has been installed in the Arena. The attendance of 18,473 at the men's final match between [[Serbia men's national water polo team|Serbia]] and [[Montenegro men's national water polo team|Montenegro]] was the highest one in water polo history.{{cite web |url=http://www.len.eu/Press/D14%20Summary%20-%20European%20Water%20Polo%20Championships,%20Belgrade.aspx |title=Serbia completes hattrick in front of 18,000 fans |publisher=[[LEN]] |date=2016-01-23 |accessdate=2016-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127225720/http://len.eu/Press/D14%20Summary%20-%20European%20Water%20Polo%20Championships,%20Belgrade.aspx |archivedate=2016-01-27 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/sport/vaterpolo/vesti.php?yyyy=2016&mm=01&dd=25&nav_id=1089131 |title=Rekord u Areni, finale gledalo 18.473 ljudi |publisher=[[B92]] |date=2016-01-25 |accessdate=2016-01-25}}]] [[File:UEFA Futsal EURO 2016 SRB SLO.jpg|thumb|250px|right| 2 – 13 February 2016: The [[UEFA Futsal Euro 2016|2016]] [[UEFA Futsal Championship]] has been held in the Arena. The overall attendance of over 100,000 was the highest one in UEFA Futsal Championship history.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/futsaleuro/news/newsid=2328342.html |title=Serbia fans set new marks |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=2016-02-13 |accessdate=2016-02-29}}]] [[File:UEFA Futsal EURO 2016 Promo Billboard.jpg|thumb|UEFA Futsal EURO 2016 Promo Billboard|thumb|250px|right| The [[UEFA Futsal Euro 2016|2016]] [[UEFA Futsal Championship]] promotional billboard, featuring an alternative Arena name. During the course of the championship, Arena has been renamed from "Kombank Arena" to "Belgrade Arena", for sponsorship reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/futsaleuro/season=2016/finals/venueguide/index.html |title=Belgrade Arena |publisher= [[UEFA]] |date=2015-09-25 |accessdate=2016-01-31}}{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/sport.294.html:584981-%D0%A3%D0%95%D0%A4%D0%90-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%80%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B0-%D0%90%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%83 |title=UEFA prekrstila "Arenu"! |publisher= [[Večernje novosti]] |date=2016-01-08 |accessdate=2016-01-31}}]] [[File:KK Crvena zvezda-CSKA TOP8.jpg|thumb|250px|right|April 18, 2016: [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena zvezda]] vs. [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], [[2015–16 Euroleague|Euroleague 2015–16]] [[2016 Euroleague Playoffs|Playoffs]] match.]] [[File:Men 60 m hurdles Belgrade 2017.jpg|thumb|250px|right| 3 – 5 March 2017: The [[2017 European Athletics Indoor Championships|2017]] [[European Athletics Indoor Championships]] has been held in the Arena.]]

==Notes== {{Cnote2 Begin|liststyle=upper-alpha}} {{Cnote2|a|This list does not include cancelled events. Nevertheless, it should be noted that two major sporting events were scheduled to be held in the Arena prior to its eventual opening, but both of these events were cancelled and subsequently relocated — the [[1994 FIBA World Championship]] due to the [[Yugoslav Wars]] and the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 757|international sanctions]] imposed to the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], and the [[1999 World Table Tennis Championships]] due to the [[NATO bombing of Yugoslavia]].}} {{Cnote2 End}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://starkarena.co.rs/events/list/?tribe_paged=1&tribe_event_display=past&lang=en List of events held in Belgrade Arena at the official website] * [http://starkarena.co.rs/?post_type=tribe_events&lang=en List of events announced to be held in Belgrade Arena at the official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Stark Arena}} [[Category:Lists of events in Serbia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Belgrade]] [[Category:Events in Serbia]] [[Category:Lists of events by venue]]
