Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
[[Food]] may be accidentally or deliberately contaminated by [[microbiology|microbiological]], chemical or physical hazards.
In contrast to microbiologically caused foodborne illness, the link between exposure and effect of chemical hazards in foods is usually complicated by cumulative low doses and the delay between exposure and the onset of symptoms. Chemical hazards include environmental contaminants, food ingredients (such as iodine), heavy metals, [[mycotoxins]], natural toxins, improper storage, processing contaminants, and veterinary medicines.
Incidents have occurred because of poor harvesting or storage of grain, use of banned veterinary products, industrial discharges, [[human error]] and deliberate adulteration and fraud.<ref name=Thomson2012>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1757-837X.2012.00129.x |title=Incidents and impacts of unwanted chemicals in food and feeds |year=2012 |last1=Thomson |first1=Barbara |last2=Poms |first2=Roland |last3=Rose |first3=Martin |journal=Quality Assurance and Safety of Crops & Foods |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=77–92}}</ref>
== Definition of an incident == An "incident" of chemical food contamination may be defined as an episodic occurrence of adverse health effects in humans (or animals that might be consumed by humans) following high exposure to particular chemicals, or instances where episodically high concentrations of chemical hazards were detected in the food chain, and traced back to a particular event.<ref name=Thomson2012/>
== Socio-economic impacts == Information on the impacts of these incidents is fragmentary and unsystematic, ranging from thousands of dollars to meet the cost of monitoring analysis, to many millions of dollars due to court prosecutions, bankruptcy, product disposal, compensation for revenue loss, damage to brand or reputation, or loss of life.<ref name=Thomson2012/>
==List of notable incidents==
===Ancient times=== *Roman Empire – There is speculation that the Romans, in particular the elite, suffered chronic to severe lead poisoning due to the ubiquity of lead in e.g. lined pots in which acidic foodstuffs were boiled, over and above any mere exposure to lead in water pipes. They also used [[Lead(II) acetate|sugar of lead]] to sweeten their wines.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://io9.com/5877587/the-first-artificial-sweetener-poisoned-lots-of-romans|title=The first artificial sweetener poisoned lots of Romans|first=Keith |last=Veronese|date=Jan 20, 2012|work=io9.com}}</ref>
===Middle Ages=== *Europe - numerous incidents of human poisoning due to the consumption of rye bread made from grain [[Ergot#History|infected with ergot fungi]]
===19th century=== *1850s - [[Swill milk scandal]] in New York *1857 – adulteration of bread with [[alum]] in London, causing rickets<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ph.ucla.edu/epi/snow/injepidemiology32_336_337_2003.pdf |title=On the adulteration of bread as a cause of rickets |publisher=Ph.ucla.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-02-09}}</ref> *1857 - poisoning of bread with arsenic in Hong Kong targeting the colonial community.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lowe|first1=Kate|title='Caution! The Bread is Poisoned': The Hong Kong Mass Poisoning of January 1857|journal=The Journal of Imperial and Commonwealth History|volume=43|issue=2 |pages=189–209 |doi=10.1080/03086534.2014.974904|year=2015|url=http://openaccess.city.ac.uk/14522/1/Caution%21%20Revised%20article%20for%20JICH%2C%20August%202014.pdf}}</ref> *1858 – [[1858 Bradford sweets poisoning|sweets poisoned with arsenic]] in Bradford, England. <!--*1890's Routine incorporation of hydrogenated vegetable oils has caused a range of health issues such as obesity and increase in coronary and related diseases (Cf. [[Trans fat]]).-->
===1900 to 1949=== *1900 - [[1900 English beer poisoning]] - Beer contaminated with [[arsenic]]. Traced to sugar manufactured with sulphuric acid that was naturally contaminated with arsenic from Spanish [[pyrites]]. An epidemic of 6070 cases in London, including 70 deaths<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(01)81229-0 |title=An Account of the Epidemic Outbreak of Arsenical Poisoning Occurring in Beer-Drinkers in the North of England and the Midland Counties in 1900 |year=1901 |last1=Septimus Reynolds |first1=Ernest |journal=The Lancet |volume=157 |issue=4038 |pages=409–52 }} Also printed as {{cite journal|pmid=20896969 |pmc=2036791 | volume=84 | title=An Account of the Epidemic Outbreak of Arsenical Poisoning occurring in Beer Drinkers in the North of England and the Midland Counties in 1900 |year=1901 |journal=Med Chir Trans |pages=409–52 | last1 = Reynolds | first1 = ES}}</ref> *1910–45 – [[Cadmium]] from mining waste contaminated rice irrigation water in Japan. Illness known as [[Itai-itai disease]] affected more than 20% of women aged over 50 years<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kasuya |first=M |title=Water pollution by cadmium and the onset of Itai-itai disease |journal=Water Science and Technology |year=1992 |volume=26 |pages=149–56 |last2=Teranishi |first2=M |last3=Aoshima |first3=K |last4=Katoh |first4=T |last5=Horiguchi |first5=H |last6=Morikawa |first6=Y |last7=Nishijo |first7=M |last8=Iwata |first8=K |url=http://www.iwaponline.com/wst/02511/wst025110149.htm |access-date=2013-11-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006194252/http://www.iwaponline.com/wst/02511/wst025110149.htm |archive-date=2014-10-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *1920 – In South Africa, 80 people suffered poisoning from eating bread contaminated with naturally occurring [[pyrrolizidine alkaloid]]s.<ref name=Kakar2010/> *1900–47 – Severe and widespread [[neurological disorder]]s due to bread flour bleached with [[Nitrogen trichloride|agene]], a process no longer in use. The denatured protein in the treated flour is toxic and causes a condition of hysteria in dogs eating biscuits made from the flour.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=10052866 |year=1998 |last1=Shaw |first1=CA |last2=Bains |first2=JS |title=Did consumption of flour bleached by the agene process contribute to the incidence of neurological disease? |volume=51 |issue=6 |pages=477–81 |journal=Medical Hypotheses |doi=10.1016/S0306-9877(98)90067-6}}</ref> *1930s – A striking example of OPIDN [[Organophosphate poisoning]] occurred during the 1930s Prohibition Era when thousands of men in the American South and Midwest developed arm and leg weakness and pain after drinking a "medicinal" alcohol substitute called "[[Jamaica ginger|Ginger Jake]]", which contained an adulterated Jamaican ginger extract containing [[tri-ortho-cresyl phosphate]] (TOCP), which resulted in partially reversible neurologic damage. The damage resulted in the limping "Jake Leg" or "Jake Walk" which were terms frequently used in the blues music of the period. Europe experienced outbreaks of TOCP poisoning from contaminated [[abortifacient]]s. Morocco experienced outbreaks of TOCP poisoning from contaminated cooking oil.
===1950 to 2000=== *1951 - [[1951 Pont-Saint-Esprit mass poisoning]] in France, probably caused by [[Ergot]]. *1950s – [[Minamata disease]]: [[Mercury (metal)|Mercury]] poisoning in fish in Japan, contaminated by industrial discharge. By 2010 more than 14,000 victims had received financial compensation.<ref>{{cite book |author1-link=Timothy S. George |last=George |first=Timothy S. |year=2002 |title=Minamata: Pollution and the Struggle for Democracy in Postwar Japan |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |publisher=Harvard University Asia Center |isbn=978-0-674-00364-4}}{{page needed|date=November 2013}}</ref> *1955 – [[Morinaga Milk arsenic poisoning incident]]: Arsenic in milk powder in Japan. An industrial grade of [[Monosodium phosphate]] additive which inadvertently contained 5–8% [[arsenic]], was added to milk fed to infants. Over 600 died, and over 6,000 people suffered health effects such as severe mental retardation. Those health effects have continued in the remaining survivors today.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.unu.edu/unupress/unupbooks/uu35ie/uu35ie09.htm|title=Chapter - 3 The arsenic milk poisoning incident|website=archive.unu.edu|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dakeishi|first=Miwako|last2=Murata|first2=Katsuyuki|last3=Grandjean|first3=Philippe|date=2006|title=Long-term consequences of arsenic poisoning during infancy due to contaminated milk powder|journal=Environmental Health|volume=5|page=31|doi=10.1186/1476-069X-5-31|issn=1476-069X|pmc=1635412|pmid=17076881}}</ref> *1957 – Chicken feed and thence chickens were contaminated with [[dioxin]]s from [[polychlorinated biphenyl]] treated cow hides in the United States. 300,000 chickens were killed or destroyed to avoid consumption<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Firestone |first1=David |year=1973 |title=Etiology of chick edema disease |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=5 |issue= |pages=59–66 |jstor=3428114 |pmid=4201768 |doi=10.1289/ehp.730559 |pmc=1474955}}</ref> *1959 – [[Moroccan oil poisoning disaster]]: several thousand people in [[Meknes]] suffer flaccid [[paralysis]] caused by deliberate contamination of cooking oil with jet engine lubricating oil containing [[tricresyl phosphate]] got as surplus from a US airbase at [[Nouaceur]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=British Journal of Industrial Medicine|title=Book Reviews: Triaryl-Phosphate Poisoning in Morocco 1959. Experiences and Findings|year=1968|volume=25 | issue = 4 |pages=330–331|pmc=1008817|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1008817/pdf/brjindmed00116-0090.pdf|last1=Hunter|first1=D.}}</ref> *1965 - Mass poisoning resulting from contamination of flour with [[4,4'-Methylenedianiline]] in Epping, Essex, United Kingdom *1968 - [[Yushō disease]]; mass poisoning resulting from rice bran oil contaminated with [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s in [[Kyūshū]], Japan *1971 – [[1971 Iraq poison grain disaster]]: 100 to 400 died of [[mercury poisoning]] by eating seeds intended for planting and treated with mercury as a [[fungicide]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Mercury Poisoning in Iraq Is Said to Kill 100 to 400|work=New York Times| date= March 9, 1972|url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20F10F93F591A7493CBA91788D85F468785F9 |accessdate= 2009-07-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.181.4096.230 |title=Methylmercury Poisoning in Iraq |year=1973 |last1=Bakir |first1=F. |last2=Damluji |first2=S. F. |last3=Amin-Zaki |first3=L. |last4=Murtadha |first4=M. |last5=Khalidi |first5=A. |last6=Al-Rawi |first6=N. Y. |last7=Tikriti |first7=S. |last8=Dahahir |first8=H. I. |last9=Clarkson |first9=T. W. |last10=Smith |first10=J. C. |last11=Doherty |first11=R. A. |journal=Science |volume=181 |issue=4096 |pages=230–41 |pmid=4719063}}: "Informed travelers from Baghdad say Iraq is in the grip of a severe mercury-poisoning outbreak. The travelers, who arrived last night, reported that 100 to 400 people had died since the outbreak began early in February."</ref> *1973 – [[Michigan PBB contamination incident]]: Widespread poisoning of people in [[Michigan]] by meat from cattle fed feed contaminated with [[polybrominated biphenyl]] in [[flame retardant]]<ref>Rachael Gleason [http://greatlakesecho.org/2010/06/04/poisoning-michigan-an-author-revisits-the-most-widespread-contamination-30-years-later/ Poisoning Michigan: Author revisits PBB crisis 30 years later] Jun 4 2010, Great Lakes Echo</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=1184446 |year=1975 |last1=Dunckel |first1=AE |title=An updating on the polybrominated biphenyl disaster in Michigan |volume=167 |issue=9 |pages=838–41 |journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3109/10408448509056268 |title=The Pbb Episode in Michigan: An Overall Appraisal |year=1985 |last1=Fries |first1=George F. |last2=Kimbrough |first2=Renate D. |journal=Critical Reviews in Toxicology |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=105–56 |pmid=3002722}}</ref> *1974–1976 – Afghanistan: widespread poisoning (an estimated 7800 people affected with hepatic veno-occlusive disease (liver damage) and about 1600 deaths) was attributed to wheat contaminated with weed seeds known as charmac (''[[Heliotropium]] popovii''. H Riedl) that contain [[pyrrolizidine alkaloid]]s.<ref name=Kakar2010/> *1976 – [[Seveso disaster|Seveso dioxin]] contamination in Italy. *1979 – in central [[Taiwan]], Over 2,000 individuals were affected by dioxin-contaminated cooking oil in what came to be called ''Yu-Cheng''.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Aoki Y |title=Polychlorinated biphenyls, polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins, and polychlorinated dibenzofurans as endocrine disrupters--what we have learned from Yusho disease |journal=Environ. Res. |volume=86 |issue=1 |pages=2–11 |year=2001 |pmid=11386736 |doi=10.1006/enrs.2001.4244 |url=}}</ref> *1981 – Spanish [[Toxic Oil Syndrome]]. Thousands permanently damaged by eating industrial [[colza oil]] denatured with [[aniline]] and sold as olive oil. There was strong suspicion that the cause was in fact insecticide in Spanish tomatoes, and that official agencies actively supported the contaminated oil position, suppressing evidence contradicting it.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/aug/25/research.highereducation |title=The Spanish cooking oil scandal |newspaper=The Guardian |date=25 August 2001 |author=Bob Woffinden |accessdate= 28 January 2016}}</ref> *1985 – [[1985 diethylene glycol wine scandal|Adulteration of Austrian wines]] with [[diethylene glycol]].<ref name="latimes" /> *1986 – Adulteration of Italian wines with [[ethylene glycol]] killed more than 18 people<ref name="latimes">{{cite news|author=Schanche, Don A.|date=April 9, 1986|title=Death Toll Stands at 18 Italy Jolted by Poisoning, Halts All Exports of Wine|work=Los Angeles Times|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/58574344.html?dids=58574344:58574344&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Apr+09%2C+1986&author=DON+A.+SCHANCHE&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Death+Toll+Stands+at+18+Italy+Jolted+by+Poisoning%2C+Halts+All+Exports+of+Wine&pqatl=google|accessdate=2009-07-20|quote=An industry source in Rome said he doubts that any of the polluted wine has reached the United States. The [[Italian Wine and Food Institute]], which represents Italian wine exporters in New York, was quoted here as saying that all Italian wine shipped to the United States is subjected to strict quality control in order to win the Italian government's seal of approval. Italy ships more wine to the United States than any other wine-producing nation, but most of its wine exports go to France and Germany, in that order, much of it in bulk for use in cutting domestic wines with higher-alcohol Italian varieties. It is far worse in scale than the scandal that virtually eliminated Austrian wines from the market last year. Some Austrian wine makers were found to have added ethylene glycol, a toxic, sweetening element, to their wines, and the discovery wiped out export sales. Ethylene glycol is also used in antifreeze. There were no known fatalities from the tainted Austrian wine.}}</ref> *1987 – [[Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation]] paid $2.2 million, then the largest fine issued, for violating the [[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]] by selling artificially flavored sugar water as apple juice. John F. Lavery, the company's vice president for operations was convicted in criminal court and sentenced to a year and a day in jail; Niels L. Hoyvald, the president of the company, also convicted, served six months of [[community service]]. Each of them also paid a $100,000 fine<ref>{{cite news|author=Traub, James|date=July 24, 1988|title=Into the Mouths of Babes|work=The New York Times|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE4DB1E38F937A15754C0A96E948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all. |accessdate=2008-10-28|quote=It is well within the reach of most white-collar criminals to assume an air of irreproachable virtue, especially when they're about to be sentenced. But there was something unusually compelling about the bearing of [[Niels L. Hoyvald]] and [[John F. Lavery]] as they stood before Judge [[Thomas C. Platt]] of the United States District Court in Brooklyn last month – especially in light of what they were being sentenced for. As president and vice president of the [[Beech-Nut]] Nutrition Corporation, Hoyvald and Lavery had sold millions of bottles of apple juice that they knew to contain little or no apple juice at all – only sugars, water, flavoring and coloring. The consumers of this bogus product were babies.}}</ref> *1989 – Milk contamination with [[dioxin]] in Belgium<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1006/enrs.2001.4274 |title=The Belgian PCB/Dioxin Incident: Analysis of the Food Chain Contamination and Health Risk Evaluation |year=2002 |last1=Bernard |first1=A |journal=Environmental Research |volume=88 |pages=1–18 |pmid=11896663 |last2=Broeckaert |first2=F |last3=De Poorter |first3=G |last4=De Cock |first4=A |last5=Hermans |first5=C |last6=Saegerman |first6=C |last7=Houins |first7=G |issue=1}}</ref> *1994 – Ground [[paprika]] in Hungary was found to be adulterated with [[lead oxide]], causing deaths of several people, while dozens of others became sick.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lead.org.au/lanv3n3/lanv3n3-6.html |title=Adulteration of Paprika in Hungary |publisher=Lead.org.au |date=2012-11-16 |accessdate=2013-02-09}}</ref> *1998 – [[1998 Delhi oil poisoning]]. In [[New Delhi]], India, edible [[mustard oil]] [[wikt:adulterate|adulterated]] with ''[[Argemone mexicana]]'' seed oil caused [[epidemic dropsy]] in thousands of people,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/pgmj.75.889.657 |title=Classic diseases revisited: Epidemic dropsy in India |year=1999 |last1=Sharma |first1=B D |last2=Malhotra |first2=S. |last3=Bhatia |first3=V. |last4=Rathee |first4=M. |journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal |volume=75 |issue=889 |pages=657–61 |pmid=10621875 |pmc=1741391}}</ref> because ''[[Argemone mexicana]]'' seed oil contains the toxic alkaloids [[sanguinarine]] and [[dihydrosanguinarine]]. The epidemic in 1998 at New Delhi is the largest so far, in which over 60 people died and more than 3000 were hospitalized. Even after that, the epidemics occurred at alarming frequency in India: in 2000 at [[Gwalior]] (2000), and in 2002 at [[Kannauj]], and in 2005 at [[Lucknow]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bbagen.2004.12.014 |title=Oxidative damage of plasma proteins and lipids in epidemic dropsy patients: Alterations in antioxidant status |year=2005 |last1=Das |first1=M |last2=Babu |first2=K |last3=Reddy |first3=N |last4=Srivastava |first4=L |journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - General Subjects |volume=1722 |issue=2 |pages=209–17 |pmid=15715957}}</ref> *1998 – In Germany and the [[Netherlands]], meat and milk were found with elevated [[dioxin]] concentrations. The dioxin was traced to citrus pulp from Brazil that had been neutralized with lime contaminated with dioxin. 92,000 tons of citrus pulp was discarded. The citrus pulp market collapsed in some European countries. A tolerance level for dioxins in citrus pulp was set by the European Commission.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0045-6535(99)00352-5 |title=Increase of the PCDD/F-contamination of milk, butter and meat samples by use of contaminated citrus pulp |year=2000 |last1=Malisch |first1=Rainer |journal=Chemosphere |volume=40 |issue=9–11 |pages=1041–53 |pmid=10739045}}</ref> *1999 – In Belgium, animal feed contaminated with dioxins and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s affected more than 2500 poultry and pig farms. This incident led to the formation of the [[Belgium Federal Food Safety Agency]]. The loss to the Belgium economy was estimated at €1500-€2000M.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.etap.2007.10.003 |title=The Belgian PCB/dioxin crisis—8 years later |year=2008 |last1=Covaci |first1=Adrian |last2=Voorspoels |first2=Stefan |last3=Schepens |first3=Paul |last4=Jorens |first4=Philippe |last5=Blust |first5=Ronny |last6=Neels |first6=Hugo |journal=Environmental Toxicology and Pharmacology |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=164–70 |pmid=21783853}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1289/ehp.01109265 |title=The Belgian PCB and Dioxin Incident of January–June 1999: Exposure Data and Potential Impact on Health |year=2001 |last1=Van Larebeke |first1=Nik |last2=Hens |first2=Luc |last3=Schepens |first3=Paul |last4=Covaci |first4=Adrian |last5=Baeyens |first5=Jan |last6=Everaert |first6=Kim |last7=Bernheim |first7=Jan L. |last8=Vlietinck |first8=Robert |last9=De Poorter |first9=Geert| displayauthors = 8 |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=109 |issue=3 |pages=265–73 |pmid=11333188 |pmc=1240245}}</ref> *1999–2000 – In Afghanistan, there were an estimated 400 cases of liver damage and over 100 deaths due to [[pyrrolizidine alkaloid]] poisoning. The food source was not identified.<ref name=Kakar2010>{{cite journal |doi=10.1155/2010/313280 |pmid=20652038 |pmc=2905904 |title=An Outbreak of Hepatic Veno-Occlusive Disease in Western Afghanistan Associated with Exposure to Wheat Flour Contaminated with Pyrrolizidine Alkaloids |year=2010 |last1=Kakar |first1=Faizullah |last2=Akbarian |first2=Zarif |last3=Leslie |first3=Toby |last4=Mustafa |first4=Mir Lais |last5=Watson |first5=John |last6=Van Egmond |first6=Hans P. |last7=Omar |first7=Mohammad Fahim |last8=Mofleh |first8=Jawad |journal=Journal of Toxicology |volume=2010 |pages=1–7}}</ref>
===2001 to 2010 === * 2001 – Spanish [[olive]] [[pomace]] oil was contaminated with [[polycyclic compound|polycyclic]] aromatic hydrocarbons. Contaminated product was recalled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/faq/olivepomoilqa/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131108073405/http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/faq/olivepomoilqa/ |archivedate=2013-11-08 |df= }} [Accessed 16 February 2010].</ref> * 2002 – In Northern Ireland, [[nitrofuran]]s were detected in 5 (of 45) samples of chicken imported from Thailand and Brazil. The product was withdrawn and destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reading.ac.uk/foodlaw/news/uk-02035.htm|title=UK Food Law News (02-35)|website=www.reading.ac.uk}}</ref> * 2002 – In the UK, [[nitrofuran]]s were detected in 16 (of 77) samples of prawns and shrimps imported from SE Asia. Affected batches were withdrawn and destroyed.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070623134331/http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/faq/51434/ ]</ref> * 2002 – In the UK and Canada, the banned antibiotic, [[chloramphenicol]], was found in honey from China<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/dhp-mps/vet/faq/faq_chloramphenicol_honey-miel-eng.php#a4|title=ARCHIVED - Chloramphenicol in Honey - Canada.ca|first=Health|last=Canada|website=www.hc-sc.gc.ca|date=2004-04-19}}</ref> * 2003 – [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|Dioxins]] were found in animal feed that was contaminated with bakery waste that had been dried by firing with waste wood.<ref name=Thomson2012/> * 2003 – The banned veterinary antibiotic [[nitrofuran]]s were found in chicken from Portugal. Poultry from 43 farms was destroyed. Nitrofurans are banned from food because of concerns including a possible increased risk of cancer in humans through long-term consumption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reading.ac.uk/foodlaw/news/uk-03018.htm|title=UK Food Law News (03-18)|website=www.reading.ac.uk}}</ref> * 2004 – Organic free-range chicken was found to contain traces of the banned veterinary drug, [[nitrofuran]]. Up to 23 tonnes of affected chicken, originating from a farm in Northern Ireland, was distributed to supermarkets across the UK resulting in a voluntary product recall and consumer warnings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/publication/fsanews43.pdf|title=Accessed 16 July 2012|author=|date=|website=food.gov.uk|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> * 2004 – The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) detected [[chloramphenicol]] in honey labelled as product of Canada. Chloramphenicol is banned for use in food-producing animals, including [[honey bee]]s, in Canada as well as in a number of other countries. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) informed Health Canada that five lots of honey labelled as "Product of Canada" were distributed in British Columbia and were found to contain residues of the banned drug [[chloramphenicol]]. A voluntary food recall occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/dhp-mps/vet/faq/faq_chloramphenicol_honey-miel-eng.php|title=ARCHIVED - Chloramphenicol in Honey - Canada.ca|first=Health|last=Canada|website=www.hc-sc.gc.ca|date=2004-04-19}}</ref> * 2004 – New Zealand [[soy milk]] manufactured with added [[kelp]] contained toxic levels of [[iodine]]. Consumption of this product was linked to five cases of [[hyperthyroidism|thyrotoxicosis]]. The manufacturer ceased production and re-formulated the product line.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-842X.2005.tb00240.x |title=A cluster of thyrotoxicosis associated with consumption of a soy milk product |year=2005 |last1=O'Connell |first1=Rebecca |last2=Parkin |first2=Lianne |last3=Manning |first3=Patrick |last4=Bell |first4=Derek |last5=Herbison |first5=Peter |last6=Holmes |first6=John |journal=Australian and New Zealand Journal of Public Health |volume=29 |issue=6 |pages=511–2 |pmid=16366059}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foodsafety.govt.nz/elibrary/industry/Nzfsa_Releases-Zealand_Food.htm |title=NZFSA releases Total Diet Survey and other residue monitoring programme results |publisher=Ministry for Primary Industries |date= |accessdate=2013-02-09}}</ref> * 2004 – New Zealand [[corn starch|cornflour]] and cornflour-containing products were contaminated with [[lead]], thought to have occurred as a result of bulk shipping of corn (maize) contaminated by previous cargo in the same storage. Affected product was distributed in New Zealand, [[Fiji]] and Australia. Four products were recalled.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130210094004/http://foodsafety.govt.nz/elibrary/industry/Source_Lead-Nzfsa_Confident.htm ]</ref> * 2004 – [[Aflatoxin]]-contaminated maize in Kenya resulted in 317 cases of [[liver|hepatic failure]] and 125 deaths.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1289/ehp.8384 |title=Case–Control Study of an Acute Aflatoxicosis Outbreak, Kenya, 2004 |year=2005 |last1=Azziz-Baumgartner |first1=Eduardo |last2=Lindblade |first2=Kimberly |last3=Gieseker |first3=Karen |last4=Rogers |first4=Helen Schurz |last5=Kieszak |first5=Stephanie |last6=Njapau |first6=Henry |last7=Schleicher |first7=Rosemary |last8=McCoy |first8=Leslie F. |last9=Misore |first9=Ambrose |last10=Decock |first10=Kevin |last11=Rubin |first11=Carol |last12=Slutsker |first12=Laurence |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=113 |issue=12 |pages=1779–83 |pmid=16330363 |pmc=1314920 |author13=The Aflatoxin Investigative Group}}</ref> * 2004 – [[Verotoxin-producing Escherichia coli|EHEC O104:H4]] in [[South Korea]], researchers pointed at contaminated [[hamburger]]s as a possible cause.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3349/ymj.2006.47.3.437 |title=A Case of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome Caused by Escherichia coli O104:H4 |year=2006 |last1=Bae |first1=Woo Kyun |last2=Lee |first2=Youn Kyoung |last3=Cho |first3=Min Seok |last4=Ma |first4=Seong Kwon |last5=Kim |first5=Soo Wan |last6=Kim |first6=Nam Ho |last7=Choi |first7=Ki Chul |journal=Yonsei Medical Journal |volume=47 |issue=3 |pages=437–9 |pmid=16807997 |pmc=2688167}}</ref><!--from the [[2011 Germany E. coli O104:H4 outbreak]] article--><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3201/eid1709.110879 |title=Escherichia coli O104:H4 from 2011 European Outbreak and Strain from Republic of Korea |year=2011 |last1=Kim |first1=Junyoung |journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases |volume=17 |issue=9 |pages=1755–6 |pmid=21888813 |pmc=3322094}}</ref> * 2005 – [[Worcester sauce]] in the UK was found to contain the banned food colouring, [[Sudan I]] dye, that was traced to imported adulterated chilli powder. 576 food products were recalled.<ref>FSA. (2005a) Action taken to remove illegal dye found in wide range of foods on sale in UK. Available at http://www.food.gov.uk/news/newsarchive/2005/feb/worcester</ref><ref>FSA. (2005b) Sudan I consolidated product list. Available at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/sudanlistno.pdf [Accessed 13 January 2011]</ref> * 2005 – [[Farmed salmon]] in British Columbia, Canada was found to contain the banned fungicide [[malachite green]]. 54 tonnes of fish was recalled. The incident resulted in an estimated $2.4-13M (USD) lost revenue.<ref>Friends of Clayoquot Sound (2005) Cancer-contaminated BC farmed salmon must be destroyed. Available at {{cite web |url=http://www.focs.ca/news/050604.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510000155/http://www.focs.ca/news/050604.asp |archivedate=2012-05-10 |df= }}[Accessed 21 March 2012]</ref> * 2006 – Pork, in China, containing [[clenbuterol]] when pigs were illegally fed the banned chemical to enhance fat burning and muscle growth, affected over 300 persons.<ref name="mb" /> * 2007 – [[2007 pet food recalls|Pet food recalls]] occurred in North America, Europe, and South Africa as a result of Chinese protein export contamination using [[melamine]] as an adulterant. * 2008 – [[2008 Chinese milk scandal|Baby milk scandal]], in China. 300,000 babies affected, 51,900 hospitalisations and 6 infant deaths. Lost revenue compensation~$30M, bankruptcy, trade restrictions imposed by 68 countries, 60 or more arrests, executions, prison sentences, and loss of consumer confidence.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1289/ehp.0900949 |title=The Melamine Incident: Implications for International Food and Feed Safety |year=2009 |last1=Gossner |first1=Céline Marie-Elise |last2=Schlundt |first2=Jørgen |last3=Ben Embarek |first3=Peter |last4=Hird |first4=Susan |last5=Lo-Fo-Wong |first5=Danilo |last6=Beltran |first6=Jose Javier Ocampo |last7=Teoh |first7=Keng Ngee |last8=Tritscher |first8=Angelika |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=117 |issue=12 |pages=1803–8 |pmid=20049196 |pmc=2799451}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1757-837X.2009.00018.x |title=Milk adulteration with melamine in China: Crisis and response |year=2009 |last1=Yang |first1=Ruijia |last2=Huang |first2=Wei |last3=Zhang |first3=Lishi |last4=Thomas |first4=Miles |last5=Pei |first5=Xiaofang |journal=Quality Assurance and Safety of Crops & Foods |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=111–116}}</ref> [[Melamine]] from the contaminated protein worked into the food chain a year later<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/27/world/asia/27china.htm ]{{dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref> * 2008 – Wheat flour contaminated with naturally-occurring [[pyrrolizidine]] alkaloids is thought to be the cause of 38 cases of [[hepatic veno-occlusive disease]] including 4 deaths in Afghanistan<ref name=Kakar2010 /> * 2008 – [[Irish pork crisis of 2008]]: Irish pork and pork products exported to 23 countries was traced and much was recalled when animal feed was contaminated with dioxins in the feed drying process. The cost of cattle and pig culling exceeded €4M, compensation for lost revenue was estimated to be €200M.<ref>BBC News. (2010) Minister heard feed toxic on TV. Available at http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/mpapps/pagetools/print/news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8567267.stm?ad=1</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsai.ie/uploadedFiles/News_Centre/Newsletters/Newsletters_Listing/FINAL(8).pdf |title=Newsletter |website=www.fsai.ie |format=PDF}}</ref> * 2008 – In Italy, it was discovered that additives included substances like [[sulfuric acid]] and [[hydrochloric acid]] had been used to dilute wines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20080404/world/italian-wine-under-investigation-for-adulteration.202817|title=Italian wine under investigation for adulteration|first=Allied Newspapers|last=Ltd|publisher=}}</ref> * 2008 – In Italy, [[dioxins and dioxin-like compounds|dioxin]] was found in [[Italian Mediterranean buffalo|buffalo]] milk from farms in Caserta. The probable source was groundwater contamination from illegal waste dumping in the [[Triangle of death (Italy)]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lyons|first1=Patrick|title=Italy’s Mozzarella Makers Fight Dioxin Scare|url=https://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/21/italys-mozzarella-makers-fight-dioxin-scare/|accessdate=4 May 2018|publisher=New York Times|date=21 March 2008}}</ref> * 2009 – Pork, in China, containing the banned chemical [[clenbuterol]] when pigs were illegally fed it to enhance fat burning and muscle growth. 70 persons were hospitalised in Guangzhou with stomach pains and diarrhoea after eating contaminated pig organs<ref name="mb">[http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/300535/skinny-pigs-poison-pork-china-battles-farm-drugs ]{{dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref> * 2009 – Hoola Pops from Mexico contaminated with lead<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30530838/|title=MSN - Outlook, Office, Skype, Bing, Breaking News, and Latest Videos|website=www.msnbc.msn.com}}</ref> * 2009 – Bonsoy-brand [[Soymilk]] in Australia, enriched with '[[Kombu]]' seaweed resulted in high levels of iodine, and 48 cases of thyroid problems. The product was voluntarily recalled and a settlement of 25 million AUS$ later reached with the victims.<ref>The Australian. (October 04, 2010) Bonsoy scare triggers calls for iodine oversight. Available at http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/bonsoy-scare-triggers-calls-for-iodine-oversight/story-fn59niix-1225933558885 [Last accessed 18 July 2011]</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=20919974 |year=2010 |last1=Crawford |first1=BA |last2=Cowell |first2=CT |last3=Emder |first3=PJ |last4=Learoyd |first4=DL |last5=Chua |first5=EL |last6=Sinn |first6=J |last7=Jack |first7=MM |title=Iodine toxicity from soy milk and seaweed ingestion is associated with serious thyroid dysfunction |volume=193 |issue=7 |pages=413–5 |journal=The Medical Journal of Australia}}</ref> * 2010 – Snakes in China were contaminated with clenbuterol when fed frogs treated with [[clenbuterol]]. 13 people were hospitalised after eating contaminated snake. There were 113 prosecutions in 2011 relating to clenbuterol, with sentences ranging from three years imprisonment to death.<ref name="mb"/>
===2011 to present=== * 2011 – Poor-quality [[illegal alcohol]] in [[West Bengal]] has resulted in an estimated 126 deaths. The alcohol may have contained [[ammonium nitrate]] and/or [[methanol]].<ref>BBC News. (2011) Who, what, why : Why are Indians dying from alcohol poisoning? Available at https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-16197280?print=true [Last accessed 28 February 2011]</ref> * 2011 – [[2011 Germany E. coli O104:H4 outbreak|German E. coli O104:H4 outbreak]] was caused by [[Verotoxin-producing Escherichia coli|EHEC]] O104:H4 contaminated [[fenugreek]] seeds imported from [[Egypt]] in 2009 and 2010, from which [[Sprouting|sprout]]s were grown in Germany. * 2011 – Vinegar from China contaminated with [[ethylene glycol]] when stored in tanks that previously contained [[antifreeze]], led to 11 deaths and an estimated 120 cases of illness.<ref>The China Times. (2011) Eleven people died from poison in vinegar. Available at http://www.thechinatimes.com/online/2011/08/1121.html [Last accessed 09 May 2011]</ref> * 2011 – Meat, eggs and egg products in Germany contaminated from animal feed containing fat contaminated with [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|dioxins]]. 4,700 German farms affected. 8,000 hens and hundreds of pigs were culled. Imports from Germany to China were banned<ref>Harrington, R. (January 2011) Dioxin-contaminated liquid egg distributed in UK, Contamination worse than feared in German dioxin scandal. Available at http://www.foodnavigator.com/content/view/print/351701 (2011-01-07) [Last accessed January 11, 2011].</ref><ref name="bbc_diofarm">{{cite news|title=BBC News – More farms closed in Germany as dioxin scare continues|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12200619|date=2011-01-15|accessdate=2013-02-25|publisher=BBC UK}}</ref> * 2012 – More than a quarter of a million chicken eggs were recalled in Germany after in-house testing discovered "excessive levels" of the poisonous chemical, [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|dioxin]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Astley|first=Mark|title=Over 250,000 eggs recalled in Germany in latest dioxin scare|url=http://www.foodqualitynews.com/Food-Alerts/Over-250-000-eggs-recalled-in-Germany-in-latest-dioxin-scare|accessdate=3 July 2012|newspaper=Food Quality News|date=21 Jun 2012}}</ref> * 2012, June – A Brazilian housewife discovered an apparently used [[condom]] at the bottom of a can of [[Knorr (brand)|Knorr]] tomato paste. Unilever was fined £3,100 ($4,800) by the [[Supreme Federal Court]]. She was awarded £1,110 ($1,700) for moral damages, as she and her family had consumed a meal prepared with the paste.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roper|first=Matt|title=British firm Unilever fined £3,100 after Brazilian housewife finds rubber CONDOM in a tin of tomato paste|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2164940/British-firm-Unilever-fined-3-000-Brazilian-housewife-finds-rubber-CONDOM-tin-tomato-paste.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=26 June 2012 |location=London |accessdate=22 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Staff|first=NR|title=Unilever Fined $4,800 After Housewife Finds Condom In Tin of Tomato Paste|url=http://www.naijapidginenglish.com/2012/06/26/unilever-fined-4800-after-housewife-finds-condom-in-tin-of-tomato-paste/|accessdate=3 July 2012|newspaper=Naija Resource|date=June 26, 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130129162156/http://www.naijapidginenglish.com/2012/06/26/unilever-fined-4800-after-housewife-finds-condom-in-tin-of-tomato-paste/|archive-date=29 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * 2012, July – Around 1 million pots of herbs had to be destroyed in North Rhine-Westphalia after treatment with an [http://www.freshplaza.com/news_detail.asp?id=98608 apparently organic plant growth strengthener] was found to contain [[DDAC]] (didecyl-dimethylammonium chloride) which resulted in contamination levels above the EU MRL of 0.01 mg/kg. This has resulted in significant additional costs to member states across the EU who put in place a [http://www.freshproduce.org.uk/docs/qacguideline.pdf monitoring programme] until February 2013 for DDAC and other quaternary ammonium compounds across a wide range of commodity groups. * 2012, August to September – Multiple [[American Licorice Company]] black [[licorice]] products recalled due to high lead levels in the products. Consuming a bag of product could give children lead levels as high as {{nowrap|13.2 micrograms/daily limit,}} double the amount regulators consider actionable.<ref>{{cite web|last=Aleccia|first=JoNel|title=Black licorice recall grows; high lead levels blamed|url=http://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/09/07/13732161-black-licorice-recall-grows-high-lead-levels-blamed?lite|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=26 February 2013}}</ref> * 2013, January – It was disclosed that [[2013 horse meat contamination in burgers scandal|horse meat contaminated beef burgers]] had been on sale in Britain and Ireland. Two companies, ABP Food Group and Liffey Meats, had supplied various supermarkets with contaminated [[Store brand|own brand]] burgers from their meat factories in the U.K. and Ireland. * 2013, February – In Germany 200 farms are suspected of selling eggs as "organic" but not adhering to the conditions required for the label.<ref name="gb_eggprobe">{{cite web|title=Probe launched into German 'organic' eggs|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130225/probe-launched-german-organic-eggs|date=2013-02-25|accessdate=2013-02-25|publisher=globalpost.com}}</ref> * 2013, March – A batch of 1800 almond cakes with butter cream and butterscotch from the Swedish supplier, Almondy, on its way to the IKEA store in [[Shanghai]] were found by Chinese authorities to have a too high amount of [[coliform bacteria]] and were subsequently destroyed.<ref name="wsj_ikeacake">{{cite news|title=IKEA Stops Cake Sales After Bacteria Found|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324178904578341910454692542|date=2013-03-05|accessdate=2013-03-05|publisher=online.wsj.com}}</ref> * 2013, March – A vegetable seller in western Germany, Rhine Main, realized that the [[lettuce]] he had been selling throughout the day contained [[Rodenticide|rat poison]]. The poison appears as small blue kernels.<ref name="tl_lett">{{cite web|title=Vegetable vendor finds rat poison in lettuce|url=http://www.thelocal.de/society/20130309-48433.html|date=2013-03-09|accessdate=2013-03-11|publisher=thelocal.de}}</ref> * 2013, February–March – Contamination with [[aflatoxin]]s results in a milk recall in Europe and a dog food recall in the United States. See [[2013 aflatoxin contamination]] for further details. * 2013, May – A Chinese crime ring was found to have passed off [[rat]], [[mink]], and [[Mammal|small mammal]] meat as [[Lamb and mutton|mutton]] for more than {{nowrap|1 million USD}} in Shanghai and Jiangsu province markets.<ref name="sc_chinarat">{{cite web|title=China: Rat meat sold as lamb in latest food scandal – International |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/international/china-rat-meat-sold-as-lamb-in-latest-food-scandal-1-2919340 |date=2013-05-03|accessdate=2013-05-08|publisher=scotsman.com}}</ref> * 2013, May – [[Halal]] Lamb Burgers contained samples of Pork DNA, affected schools 19 schools in Leicester, UK.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2013/may/09/pork-school-halal-lamb-burgers | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Pork found in school halal lamb burgers | date=9 May 2013}}</ref> * |first4=Alfredo |last5=Salomão |first5=Cristolde |last6=Oliveira |first6=Fernanda |last7=Ismael |first7=Hamida |last8=Saeze |first8=Cristovão |last9=Mosse |first9=Carla |date=2017-11-16 |title=Description of a mass poisoning in a rural district in Mozambique: The first documented bongkrekic acid poisoning in Africa |journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases |volume=66 |issue=9 |pages=1400–1406 |doi=10.1093/cid/cix1005 |issn=1537-6591 |pmid=29155976|pmc=5908738 }}</ref> * 2015, April – Contaminated [[Bubble tea|milk tea]] resulted in the deaths of two individuals and affected another<ref name="MBmilktea">{{cite news|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/2-dead-1-critical-from-milk-tea-poisoning-in-sampaloc/|title=2 dead, 1 critical from alleged milk tea poisoning in Sampaloc|date=11 April 2015|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]|accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> in Sampaloc, [[Manila]],<ref name="bna">{{cite news|url=http://www.businessnewsasia.com/20150410523800-milk-tea-poisoning-kills-2-in-philippines/|title=Milk Tea Poisoning Kills 2 in Philippines|work=BusinessNewsAsia|accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="Chavez">{{cite news|url=http://www.tempo.com.ph/2015/04/13/ecowaste-calls-for-strict-enforcement-vs-toxic-chemicals/|title=EcoWaste calls for strict enforcement vs toxic chemicals|last=Chavez|first=Chito|date=13 April 2015|work=Tempo|accessdate=13 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413050730/http://www.tempo.com.ph/2015/04/13/ecowaste-calls-for-strict-enforcement-vs-toxic-chemicals/|archive-date=13 April killed in the incident; Abrigo denied the allegations,<ref name="lloyd">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/485234/news/metromanila/murder-charges-filed-vs-ergo-cha-milk-tea-shop-owner-s-son|title=Murder charges filed vs. Ergo Cha milk tea shop owner's million L) of ice cream after an outbreak of [[listeria]] at one of their production facilities led to ten hospitalizations and three deaths.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gibson |first1=Kate |title=Blue Bell's comeback continues after deadly listeria outbreak |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/blue-bell-attempts-comeback-after-deadly-listeria-outbreak/ |website=MoneyWatch |publisher=[[CBS News]] Coli Scare Spreads To Walmart, Starbucks, Target|author=|date=|website=www.msn.com|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> * 2016, February–March – Mars Chocolates contamination incident, in which plastic found in candy bars lead to a recall affecting 55 countries.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Quinn|first1=Beth|title=Mars recalls chocolate bars in 55 countries after plastic found in product|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/23/mars-chocolate-product-recalls-snickers-milky-way-celebrations-germany-netherlands|accessdate=12 October 2016|work=The Guardian|date=23 February 2016}}</ref> *2016, April–May, CRF Frozen Foods recalled over 400 frozen food products due to listeria outbreak that sickened 8 people.<ref name="seattletimes.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/health/layoffs-grow-at-pasco-frozen-food-plant-closed-by-listeria-recall/|title=Amid frozen-food recall, more than 300 laid off at Pasco plant|date=28 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> *2016, April–May - [[2016 Punjab sweet poisoning]] *2017, [[2017 Fipronil eggs contamination]] in Europe * [[2017-18 South African Listeriosis outbreak]]

A '''mass mortality event''' (MME) is an incident that kills a vast number of a single species in a short period of time.<ref name="fey">{{cite journal|last1=Fey|first1=Samuel B.|last2=Siepielski|first2=Adam M.|last3=Nusslé|first3=Sébastien|last4=Cervantes-Yoshida|first4=Kristina|last5=Hwan|first5=Jason L.|last6=Huber|first6=Eric R.|last7=Fey|first7=Maxfield J.|last8=Catenazzi|first8=Alessandro|last9=Carlson|first9=Stephanie M.|title=Recent shifts in the occurrence, cause, and magnitude of animal mass mortality events|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date=27 January 2015|volume=112|issue=4|pages=1083–1088|doi=10.1073/pnas.1414894112|pmid=25583498|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/112/4/1083|accessdate=26 February 2018|pmc=4313809}}</ref> The event may put a species at risk of [[extinction]] or upset an [[ecosystem]].<ref name="DD">{{cite news|last1=Derbyshire|first1=David|title=The terrifying phenomenon that is pushing species towards extinction|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/25/mass-mortality-events-animal-conservation-climate-change?CMP=fb_us#link_time=1519565187|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=25 February 2018|language=en}}</ref> This is distinct from the mass die-off associated with short lived and synchronous emergent insect [[taxa]] which is a regular and non-catastrophic occurrence.<ref name="HoI">{{cite book|first1=|editor1-last=Rasnitsyn|editor1-first=Alexandr P.|title=History of insects|date=2002|publisher=Springer|location=Dordrecht, The Netherlands|isbn=9781402000263|page=28|edition=Reprint.|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=qTA_Qee-unYC&pg=PA28|accessdate=26 February 2018}}</ref>
Causes of MME's include disease and human-related activities such as pollution. Climatic extremes and other environmental influences such as oxygen stress in aquatic environments play a role, as does starvation. In many MME's there are multiple stressors.<ref name="DD" /> An analysis of such events from 1940 to 2012 found that these events have become more common for birds, fish and marine invertebrates, but have declined for amphibians and reptiles and not changed for mammals.<ref name="JJL">{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Jane J.|title=Mass Animal Die-Offs Are on the Rise, Killing Billions and Raising Questions|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2015/01/150113-mass-die-off-disease-animals-environment-science/|accessdate=25 February 2018|publisher=[[National Geographic]]|date=14 January 2015}}</ref>
==Known mass mortality events==
'''Harbour Seals (1988)'''
In 1988, the death of 20,000 [[harbour seals]] in the [[North Sea]] was found to be due to [[phocine distemper virus]]. Ten years later two bacteria were implicated in the death of 1600 [[New Zealand sea lion]]s. On [[Marion Island]] in 2007, some 250–300 adult male [[Subantarctic fur seal]] died in a two-week period. It was suggested but not proven that this gender-biased mortality was caused by [[Streptococcus sanguinis]] which was carried by the [[house mouse]], an alien species accidentally introduced in the 1800s.<ref name="dB">{{cite journal|last1=de Bruyn|first1=P. J. Nico|last2=Bastos|first2=Armanda D. S.|last3=Eadie|first3=Candice|last4=Tosh|first4=Cheryl A.|last5=Bester|first5=Marthán N.|last6=Hansen|first6=Dennis Marinus|title=Mass Mortality of Adult Male Subantarctic Fur Seals: Are Alien Mice the Culprits?|journal=PLoS ONE|date=19 November 2008|volume=3|issue=11|pages=e3757|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0003757|pmid=19018284|pmc=2582944}}</ref>
'''Mule Deer (2003)'''
In the [[Inyo National Forest]] there are several records of large numbers of migrating [[mule deer]] falling to their deaths by slipping on ice while crossing mountain passes. This has occurred when heavy snowfalls have persisted until fall, and have been turned to ice by frequent thawing and freezing.<ref name="SR">{{cite news|last1=Rea|first1=Sarah|title=A Slippery Slope|url=http://thesheetnews.com/2017/11/22/a-slippery-slope/|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=The Sheet|date=22 Nov 2017}}</ref> In 2003 a rain-on-snow event encased the ground in ice, resulting in the starvation of 20,000 [[muskoxen]] on [[Banks Island]] in the Canadian Arctic.<ref name="JP">{{cite journal|last1=Putkonen|first1=Jaakko|last2=Grenfell|first2=Thomas C.|last3=Rennert|first3=Kevin|last4=Bitz|first4=Cecilia|last5=Jacobson|first5=Paul|last6=Russell|first6=Don|title=Rain on Snow: Little Understood Killer in the North|journal=[[Eos (magazine)|Eos]]|date=30 June 2009|volume=90|issue=26|pages=221–222|doi=10.1029/2009EO260002}}</ref><ref name="JB">{{cite journal|last1=Berger|first1=J.|last2=Hartway|first2=C.|last3=Gruzdev|first3=A.|last4=Johnson|first4=M.|title=Climate Degradation and Extreme Icing Events Constrain Life in Cold-Adapted Mammals|journal=Scientific Reports|date=18 January 2018|volume=8|issue=1|pages=1156|doi=10.1038/s41598-018-19416-9|pmid=29348632|pmc=5773676|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-19416-9|accessdate=25 February 2018}}</ref>
'''Saiga Antelope (2015)'''
In 2015, some 200,000 [[saiga antelope]] died within a period of one week in a 20 km<sup>2</sup> area of the [[Betpak-Dala]] desert region of [[Kazakhstan]]. They had gathered in large groups for their annual calving. It was determined that warm and humid temperatures had caused [[Pasteurella multocida]], a bacteria that normally live harmlessly in their tonsils, to cross into their bloodstream and cause [[Hemorrhagic septicemia]]. This event wiped out 60% of the population of this [[critically endangered]] species. Mass mortality events are not uncommon for saiga. In 1981, 70,000 died, in 1988 there were 200,000 deaths and more recently in 2010 12,000 died.<ref name="UNE">{{cite web|title=Catastrophic Collapse of Saiga Antelopes in Central Asia|url=https://www.unenvironment.org/news-and-stories/press-release/catastrophic-collapse-saiga-antelopes-central-asia|website=UN Environment|accessdate=25 February 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name="DD" />
==See also== *[[Australian flying fox die-offs]] *[[Harmful algal bloom]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Natural disasters]] [[Category:Biological events]]

The '''Miklós Schweitzer Competition''' (''Schweitzer Miklós Matematikai Emlékverseny'' in Hungarian) is an annual [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[mathematics]] competition for [[university]] undergraduates, established in 1949.
It is named after Miklós Schweitzer (1 February 1923 – 28 January 1945), a young Hungarian mathematician who died under the [[Siege of Budapest]] in the [[Second World War]].
The Schweitzer contest is uniquely high-level among mathematics competitions. The problems, written by prominent Hungarian mathematicians, are challenging and require in-depth knowledge of the fields represented. The competition is open-book and competitors are allowed ten days to come up with solutions.
The problems on the competition can be classified roughly in the following categories: 1. Algebra 2. Combinatorics 3. Theory of Functions 4. Geometry 5. Measure Theory 6. Number Theory 7. Operators 8. Probability Theory 9. Sequences and Series 10. Topology 11. Set Theory
Recently a [https://concourssmf2018.sciencesconf.org/ similar competition] has been started in France.
==References== *{{cite book | editor=[[Gábor J. Székely|Székely, Gábor J.]] | title=Contests in Higher Mathematics: Miklós Schweitzer Competitions 1962–1991 | publisher=New York, Springer-Verlag | year=1996 | isbn=0-387-94588-1}} * Contests in higher mathematics (Hungary, 1949–1961). In memoriam Miklós Schweitzer. (G. Szasz, L. Geher, I. Kovacs, L. Pinter, eds), ''Akadémiai Kiadó'', Budapest, 1968 260 pp. * Miklós Schweitzer Competition Problems in [http://www.math.u-szeged.hu/~mmaroti/schweitzer/ recent years] * [http://www.artofproblemsolving.com/community/c3253_mikls_schweitzer Problems of the Miklós Schweitzer Memorial Competition at http://artofproblemsolving.com/]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Miklos Schweitzer Competition}} [[Category:Mathematics competitions]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1949]] [[Category:Student events]]
{{math-competition-stub}}
